The Mount Laurel doctrine is a significant judicial doctrine of the New Jersey State Constitution. The doctrine requires that municipalities use their zoning powers in an affirmative manner to provide a realistic opportunity for the production of housing affordable to low- and moderate-income households.
The doctrine takes its name from the lead case in which it was first pronounced by the New Jersey Supreme Court in 1975: Southern Burlington County N.A.A.C.P. v. Mount Laurel Township (commonly called Mount Laurel I), in which the plaintiffs challenged the zoning ordinance of Mount Laurel Township, New Jersey, on the grounds that it operated to exclude low and moderate income persons from obtaining housing in the municipality.
story:
The Mount Laurel doctrine is a legal requirement for municipalities in New Jersey to ensure that their zoning laws do not discriminate against low- and moderate-income households by denying them affordable housing opportunities. The doctrine was established in a 1975 court case, Southern Burlington County N.A.A.C.P. v. Mount Laurel Township, in which the plaintiffs argued that Mount Laurel Township's zoning ordinance unfairly excluded low- and moderate-income individuals from housing in the area.

Story:
Once upon a time, in a small town called Mount Laurel, there lived a group of low-income families who were struggling to find affordable housing. The town's zoning laws made it difficult for developers to build affordable housing, and as a result, most of the homes in the area were expensive and out of reach for many residents.

A group of concerned citizens, led by a local NAACP chapter, decided to take action. They filed a lawsuit against the township, arguing that the zoning laws were unfair and discriminatory. They claimed that the laws were designed to keep low-income families out of the area, and that the township had a responsibility to ensure that all residents had access to affordable housing.

The case made its way to the New Jersey Supreme Court, which ruled in favor of the plaintiffs. The court declared that municipalities have an obligation to use their zoning powers in an affirmative manner to provide a realistic opportunity for the production of housing affordable to low- and moderate-income households. This became known as the Mount Laurel doctrine.

The township was required to revise its zoning laws to allow for more affordable housing options. As a result, more low- and moderate-income families were able to find affordable homes in the area. The township also worked with developers to build new affordable housing units, which helped to diversify the community and promote economic growth.

The Mount Laurel doctrine has since been used as a model for other states and municipalities to ensure that all residents have access to affordable housing. It has been a powerful tool in the fight against discrimination and has helped to create more inclusive and diverse communities.

In summary, the Mount Laurel doctrine is a legal requirement for municipalities in New Jersey to ensure that their zoning laws do not discriminate against low- and moderate-income households by denying them affordable housing opportunities. The doctrine was established in a 1975 court case and has since been used as a model for other states and municipalities to promote affordable housing and diversity in communities.

intro_text:
In English law, natural justice is technical terminology for the rule against bias (nemo iudex in causa sua) and the right to a fair hearing (audi alteram partem). While the term natural justice is often retained as a general concept, it has largely been replaced and extended by the general "duty to act fairly".
The basis for the rule against bias is the need to maintain public confidence in the legal system. Bias can take the form of actual bias, imputed bias, or apparent bias. Actual bias is very difficult to prove in practice whereas imputed bias, once shown, will result in a decision being void without the need for any investigation into the likelihood or suspicion of bias. Cases from different jurisdictions currently apply two tests for apparent bias: the "reasonable suspicion of bias" test and the "real likelihood of bias" test. One view that has been taken is that the differences between these two tests are largely semantic and that they operate similarly.
The right to a fair hearing requires that individuals should not be penalized by decisions affecting their rights or legitimate expectations unless they have been given prior notice of the case, a fair opportunity to answer it, and the opportunity to present their own case. The mere fact that a decision affects rights or interests is sufficient to subject the decision to the procedures required by natural justice. In Europe, the right to a fair hearing is guaranteed by Article 6(1) of the European Convention on Human Rights, which is said to complement the common law rather than replace it.
story:
Natural justice is a legal concept that ensures fairness in decision-making processes. It's like a referee in a game, making sure neither team has an unfair advantage. In English law, natural justice means that no one can judge their own case (nemo iudex in causa sua) and everyone has the right to a fair hearing (audi alteram partem).

Imagine you're a player in a game, and the referee is also a player on the opposing team. That wouldn't be fair, right? That's what nemo iudex in causa sua is all about. It means that no one can make a decision in a case where they have a personal interest. It's like asking a teacher to grade their own child's exam - they might be a bit biased!

Now, let's talk about the right to a fair hearing. Imagine you're accused of stealing a cookie from the cookie jar. You want to explain your side of the story, but the cookie police don't give you a chance to speak. They just say, "You're guilty! No cookies for you!" That's not fair, is it? Audi alteram partem means that everyone has the right to tell their side of the story and have their voice heard.

There are two tests to check if a decision is fair: the "reasonable suspicion of bias" test and the "real likelihood of bias" test. It's like having two different referees checking if a player is playing fairly. One referee might say, "Hey, that player looks like they're cheating. Let's investigate." The other referee might say, "I'm not sure, but there's a chance they might be cheating. Let's take a closer look." Both referees are trying to make sure the game is fair, but they have different ways of checking.

In Europe, the right to a fair hearing is protected by Article 6(1) of the European Convention on Human Rights. It's like having a super referee who makes sure all the referees in the game are being fair. They can't replace the referees, but they can help make sure everyone follows the rules.

So, natural justice is like having a fair referee in a game. It ensures that no one has an unfair advantage and everyone gets to tell their side of the story. It's an important concept in law to make sure decisions are made fairly and justly.

intro_text:
Some philosophers distinguish two types of rights, natural rights and legal rights.
Natural rights are those that are not dependent on the laws or customs of any particular culture or government, and so are universal, fundamental and inalienable (they cannot be repealed by human laws, though one can forfeit their enjoyment through one's actions, such as by violating someone else's rights). Natural law is the law of natural rights.
Legal rights are those bestowed onto a person by a given legal system (they can be modified, repealed, and restrained by human laws). The concept of positive law is related to the concept of legal rights.Natural law first appeared in ancient Greek philosophy, and was referred to by Roman philosopher Cicero. It was subsequently alluded to in the Bible, and then developed in the Middle Ages by Catholic philosophers such as Albert the Great and his pupil Thomas Aquinas. During the Age of Enlightenment, the concept of natural laws was used to challenge the divine right of kings, and became an alternative justification for the establishment of a social contract, positive law, and government  and thus legal rights  in the form of classical republicanism. Conversely, the concept of natural rights is used by others to challenge the legitimacy of all such establishments.
The idea of human rights derives from theories of natural rights. Those rejecting a distinction between human rights and natural rights view human rights as the successor that is not dependent on natural law, natural theology, or Christian theological doctrine. Natural rights, in particular, are considered beyond the authority of any government or international body to dismiss. The 1948 United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights is an important legal instrument enshrining one conception of natural rights into international soft law. Natural rights were traditionally viewed as exclusively negative rights, whereas human rights also comprise positive rights. Even on a natural rights conception of human rights, the two terms may not be synonymous.
The concept of natural rights is not universally accepted, partly due to its religious associations and perceived incoherence. Some philosophers argue that natural rights do not exist and that legal rights are the only rights; for instance, Jeremy Bentham called natural rights "simple nonsense".
story:
Natural rights and legal rights are two different types of rights that people have. Natural rights are universal, fundamental, and cannot be taken away by any government or law. They are based on the idea of natural law, which comes from ancient Greek and Roman philosophy and was developed by Catholic philosophers in the Middle Ages. The concept of natural rights was used to challenge the divine right of kings and to establish the idea of a social contract and government. Human rights are derived from theories of natural rights and are considered to be beyond the authority of any government or international body to dismiss.

On the other hand, legal rights are those that are given to people by a particular legal system. They can be changed, repealed, or restricted by human laws. Legal rights are also known as positive law. Some philosophers argue that natural rights do not exist and that legal rights are the only rights.

The difference between natural and legal rights is important because it affects how we think about government and the role of law in society. If natural rights exist, then they provide a basis for limiting the power of government and protecting individual freedoms. If, on the other hand, legal rights are the only rights that exist, then government has the power to decide what rights people have and how they should be protected.

The idea of natural rights has been influential in the development of human rights, which are enshrined in international law. However, not everyone agrees with the concept of natural rights, and some argue that it is incoherent or has religious associations that are no longer acceptable. Despite these criticisms, the idea of natural rights remains an important part of legal and political philosophy.

intro_text:
In the criminal law of many nations, necessity may be either a possible justification or an exculpation for breaking the law. Defendants seeking to rely on this defense argue that they should not be held liable for their actions as a crime because their conduct was necessary to prevent some greater harm and when that conduct is not excused under some other more specific provision of law such as self defense. As a matter of political expediency, states usually allow some classes of person to be excused from liability when they are engaged in socially useful functions but intentionally cause injury, loss or damage. 
For example, a drunk driver might contend that they drove their car to get away from being kidnapped (cf. North by Northwest).  Most common law and civil law jurisdictions recognize this defense, but only under limited circumstances. Generally, the defendant must affirmatively show (i.e., introduce some evidence) that (a) the harm they sought to avoid outweighs the danger of the prohibited conduct they are charged with; (b) they had no reasonable alternative; (c) they ceased to engage in the prohibited conduct as soon as the danger passed; and (d) they themselves did not create the danger they sought to avoid.  Thus, with the "drunk driver" example cited above, the necessity defense will not be recognized if the defendant drove further than was reasonably necessary to get away from the kidnapper, or if some other reasonable alternative was available to them.
For another example, the fire services and other civil defence organizations have a general duty to keep the community safe from harm. If a fire or flood is threatening to spread out of control, it may be reasonably necessary to destroy other property to form a fire break, or to trespass on land to throw up mounds of earth to prevent the water from spreading. 
These examples have the common feature of individuals intentionally breaking the law because they believe it to be urgently necessary to protect others from harm, but some states distinguish between a response to a crisis arising from an entirely natural cause (an inanimate force of nature), e.g. a fire from a lightning strike or rain from a storm, and a response to an entirely human crisis. Thus, parents who lack the financial means to feed their children cannot use necessity as a defense if they steal food. The existence of welfare benefits and strategies other than self-help defeat the claim of an urgent necessity that cannot be avoided in any way other than by breaking the law. 
Further, some states apply a test of proportionality, where the defense would only be allowed where the degree of harm actually caused was a reasonably proportionate response to the degree of harm threatened. This is a legal form of costbenefit analysis.
story:
Necessity in criminal law refers to a situation where an individual breaks the law to prevent a greater harm from occurring. This defense can be used in cases where the individual had no other choice and their actions were proportionate to the threat they were facing.

For example, imagine a person is driving drunk and gets kidnapped. They might argue that they had to drive to get away from the kidnapper, even though they were drunk, to prevent harm to themselves. However, if they drove recklessly and put others in danger, their actions might not be considered necessary, and they could still be charged with a crime.

Another example is a firefighter who breaks into a burning building to save people trapped inside. They might argue that their actions were necessary to prevent harm to the people trapped in the building. However, if they caused more damage to the building than necessary, their actions might not be considered proportionate, and they could still face legal consequences.

In some cases, individuals might argue that they had to break the law to prevent a greater harm, but the law might not recognize their actions as necessary. For instance, a parent who steals food to feed their children might argue that they had no other choice, but the law might not consider their actions necessary, as there are other ways to get food, such as seeking help from a food bank or government assistance.

In summary, necessity in criminal law refers to a situation where an individual breaks the law to prevent a greater harm, but their actions must be proportionate to the threat they are facing, and there must be no other reasonable alternative available to them.

intro_text: Negligence (Lat. negligentia) is a failure to exercise appropriate and/or ethical ruled care expected to be exercised amongst specified circumstances. The area of tort law known as negligence involves harm caused by failing to act as a form of carelessness possibly with extenuating circumstances. The core concept of negligence is that people should exercise reasonable care in their actions, by taking account of the potential harm that they might foreseeably cause to other people or property.Someone who suffers loss caused by another's negligence may be able to sue for damages to compensate for their harm. Such loss may include physical injury, harm to property, psychiatric illness, or economic loss. The law on negligence may be assessed in general terms according to a five-part model which includes the assessment of duty, breach, actual cause, proximate cause, and damages.
story:
Negligence refers to the failure to exercise reasonable care, which results in harm or injury to another person or their property. In essence, it means that individuals have a responsibility to act with care and take steps to prevent causing harm to others. When someone fails to meet this responsibility, they can be held liable for any damages or injuries that result.

Story:

Meet Sarah, a busy college student who lives in a shared apartment with her friends. One evening, Sarah was in a rush to get to class and accidentally left the stove on while she left the apartment. Rachel quickly called the fire department, and they were able to put out the fire before it spread to the rest of the apartment. However, the kitchen was severely damaged, and Rachel suffered from smoke inhalation.

Rachel went to the hospital and was treated for her injuries. She then decided to sue Sarah for negligence, claiming that her carelessness had caused the fire and her injuries. Sarah was devastated by the news and didn't know what to do. She had never intended to cause any harm and didn't think her actions would result in a fire.

The case went to court, and the judge had to determine whether Sarah was negligent and if her actions had caused the harm to Rachel. The judge explained to the jury that negligence occurs when someone fails to exercise reasonable care, and that carelessness can take many forms. In this case, Sarah had a responsibility to ensure that the stove was turned off before leaving the apartment, especially since she knew that her roommates would be returning home later that day.

The jury decided that Sarah was indeed negligent and that her actions had caused the fire and Rachel's injuries. They awarded Rachel damages to cover the cost of her medical treatment and the damage to the apartment. Sarah was devastated by the outcome, but she realized that she had learned an important lesson about the importance of taking responsibility for her actions and exercising reasonable care.

In this story, Sarah's negligence resulted in harm to her roommate and damage to their property. The court had to determine whether Sarah's actions were reasonable under the circumstances, and they ultimately decided that she had failed to meet her responsibility to act with care. intro_text:
Nemo judex in causa sua (or nemo judex in sua causa) (which, in Latin, literally means "no-one is judge in his own cause") is a principle of natural justice that no person can judge a case in which they have an interest. In many jurisdictions the rule is very strictly applied to any appearance of a possible bias, even if there is actually none: "Justice must not only be done, but must be seen to be done".This principle may also be called:

nemo judex idoneus in propria causa est
nemo judex in parte sua
nemo judex in re sua
nemo debet esse judex in propria causa
in propria causa nemo judexThe legal effect of a breach of natural justice is normally to stop the proceedings and render any judgment invalid; it should be quashed or appealed, but may be remitted for a valid re-hearing.
story:
Nemo_iudex_in_causa_sua means that no one can be a judge in a case where they have a personal interest. This principle is based on the idea that justice must be impartial and unbiased. It's like having a referee in a game who is also a player on one of the teams - it wouldn't be fair because they might favor their own team. In the legal system, this means that a judge or decision-maker cannot have a personal stake in the outcome of a case. If they do, it could look like they're not being fair, even if they actually are.

Imagine you're a player in a basketball game, and the referee is also the coach of the other team. You might feel like the referee is not being fair when they make calls against your team, even if they're actually doing their best to be impartial. That's kind of like what nemo_iudex_in_causa_sua is all about - making sure that the person making decisions in a legal case doesn't have a personal interest in the outcome.

This principle is important because it helps ensure that the legal system is fair and trustworthy. If people feel like the system is biased or corrupt, they might not trust it, and that could lead to problems in society. So, the legal system takes the appearance of bias very seriously, even if there actually isn't any. It's better to err on the side of caution and have a different person make the decision than to risk looking like the system isn't fair.

If a breach of natural justice occurs, it can have serious consequences. It might mean that a judgment is invalid, and the case has to be re-heard with a different decision-maker. It's like if the referee in the basketball game was also the coach of the other team, and they made a bad call that affected the outcome of the game. The game might have to be replayed with a different referee to make sure it's fair.

In summary, nemo_iudex_in_causa_sua is a principle that helps ensure the legal system is fair and impartial. It means that no one can be a judge in a case where they have a personal interest, and it's important because it helps build trust in the system. If there's a breach of this principle, it can have serious consequences, like a judgment being invalidated and a case being re-heard.
concept_question:

B) A judge can decide a case in which they have a personal interest.
C) A judge must disclose any personal interest they have in a case.

The principle of nemo_iudex_in_causa_sua is not just about disclosing personal interests, but also about ensuring that the decision-maker does not have any personal interest in the outcome of the case.

Option D is a metaphor used in the story to explain the concept, but it is not an accurate description of the concept itself.
ending_question:

This is in line with the principle of nemo_iudex_in_causa_sua, which states that no one can be a judge in a case where they have a personal interest.

intro_text: Nolle prosequi, abbreviated nol or nolle pros, is legal Latin meaning "to be unwilling to pursue". It is a type of prosecutorial discretion in common law, used for prosecutors' declarations that they are voluntarily ending a criminal case before trial or before a verdict is rendered; it is a kind of motion to dismiss and contrasts with an involuntary dismissal. This has been used frequently in the state of Virginia.
story:
Nolle prosequi is a legal term that means "to be unwilling to pursue." It's like a prosecutor saying, "I'm dropping the charges, I don't want to continue with this case." It's not because they have to, but because they want to. It's a way for prosecutors to dismiss a case before it goes to trial or before a verdict is reached. It's different from when a judge dismisses a case because the prosecutor is choosing to drop the charges. This happens a lot in the state of Virginia.

Story:

Once upon a time, there was a young man named John who was accused of stealing a car. He was arrested and charged with grand theft auto. The prosecutor, Ms. Smith, was assigned to the case. She reviewed the evidence and realized that there was a good chance that John might be found not guilty. She also discovered that John had a clean record and this was his first offense. Ms. Smith decided that it would be best to exercise her prosecutorial discretion and drop the charges against John. She filed a nolle prosequi, effectively ending the case before it went to trial. John was released from jail and was able to move on with his life without the burden of a criminal record.

In this story, Ms. Smith used her power as a prosecutor to decide not to pursue the case against John. She chose to drop the charges because she didn't think it was likely that John would be found guilty and because she wanted to give him a second chance. This is an example of nolle prosequi in action.
concept_question:

C) A prosecutor's decision to drop charges against a defendant before trial or a verdict.

It is not a request to a judge or an order from a judge, but rather a unilateral decision made by the prosecutor. Therefore, option (C) accurately describes the concept of nolle prosequi.
ending_question:

limitation_question:

The prosecutor has the power to use nolle prosequi in any case where they choose to exercise their prosecutorial discretion.

intro_text:
Nominative use, also "nominative fair use", is a legal doctrine that provides an affirmative defense to trademark infringement as enunciated by the United States Ninth Circuit, by which a person may use the trademark of another as a reference to describe the other product, or to compare it to their own. Nominative use may be considered to be either related to, or a type of "trademark fair use" (sometimes called "classic fair use" or "statutory fair use").  All "trademark fair use" doctrines, however classified, are distinct from the fair use doctrine in copyright law.  However, the fair use of a trademark may be protected under copyright laws depending on the complexity or creativity of the mark as a design logo.The nominative use test essentially states that one party may use or refer to the trademark of another if:

The product or service cannot be readily identified without using the trademark (e.g. trademark is descriptive of a person, place, or product attribute).
The user only uses as much of the mark as is necessary for the identification (e.g. the words but not the font or symbol).
The user does nothing to suggest sponsorship or endorsement by the trademark holder.  This applies even if the nominative use is commercial, and the same test applies for metatags.Furthermore, if a use is found to be nominative, then by the definition of non-trademark uses, it can not dilute the trademark.Nominative use does not require that ownership of the trademark be acknowledged, for example by use of a sentence such as "UNIX is a registered trademark of The Open Group". Such statements may, however, be required by the terms of a license agreement between the parties, and they may be prudent (and courteous) as a way of preventing misunderstandings or allegations of passing off.
story:
Nominative use, also known as nominative fair use, is a legal doctrine that allows someone to use another person's trademark to describe or compare their own product or service. This doctrine is a defense against trademark infringement and is different from the fair use doctrine in copyright law.

To qualify for nominative use, the following conditions must be met:

1. The trademark is necessary to identify the product or service.
2. Only a limited amount of the trademark is used, just enough to identify it.
3. There is no suggestion that the trademark holder endorses or sponsors the user's product or service.

For example, if a company called "ABC" makes a product called "SuperGlue," another company called "XYZ" can use the term "SuperGlue" in their advertising to compare their own product to ABC's SuperGlue, as long as they don't suggest that ABC endorses their product.

It's important to note that nominative use does not require the user to acknowledge the trademark owner's ownership, but it's still a good idea to do so to avoid any misunderstandings or allegations of passing off.

In summary, nominative use is a legal doctrine that allows someone to use another person's trademark to describe or compare their own product or service, as long as they meet certain conditions and don't suggest any endorsement or sponsorship by the trademark holder.

intro_text:
Non bis in idem (sometimes rendered non-bis in idem or ne bis in idem) which translates literally from Latin as 'not twice in the same [thing]', is a legal doctrine to the effect that no legal action can be instituted twice for the same cause of action. It is a legal concept originating in Roman civil law, but it is essentially the equivalent of the double jeopardy doctrine found in common law jurisdictions, and similar peremptory plea (autrefois acquit/convict, 'previously acquitted/convicted') in some modern civil law countries.
The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights guarantees the right to be free from double jeopardy; however, it does not apply to prosecutions by two different sovereigns (unless the relevant extradition treaty or other agreement between the countries expresses a prohibition). The Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court employs a modified form of non bis in idem.
story:
Non bis in idem is a legal doctrine that protects individuals from being tried twice for the same crime. It's like double jeopardy, but it's not just limited to criminal cases. It also applies to civil lawsuits.

Imagine you're a farmer named John. You grow beautiful tomatoes, and you sell them at the local market. One day, a customer named Sarah buys some tomatoes from you, but she claims they're rotten and sues you for breach of contract. You go to court, and the judge rules in your favor. Sarah can't just turn around and sue you again for the same tomatoes, that would be unfair, right? That's what non bis in idem is all about.

Now, let's say the government wants to prosecute you for selling rotten tomatoes. They can't just use the same evidence that Sarah used in her lawsuit against you. That would be double jeopardy. But, if they have new evidence that you intentionally sold rotten tomatoes, they might be able to prosecute you. It's like the difference between a rematch and a do-over.

Non bis in idem applies in international law too. If another country wants to prosecute you for something that you've already been acquitted of in your home country, they can't just use the same evidence. They'd have to find new evidence to justify a new trial. It's like a game of legal limbo - how low can you go?

The Rome Statute, which is like a rulebook for international criminal cases, has a modified version of non bis in idem. It's like a special edition of the game with extra rules. It allows for a retrial if there's new evidence, but it also protects people from being tried twice for the same crime in different countries. It's like a legal safety net to prevent double jeopardy.

In summary, non bis in idem is a legal doctrine that protects people from being tried twice for the same thing. It's like double jeopardy, but it applies to civil cases too, and it's an important principle in international law. It's all about fairness and making sure that people don't get stuck in a never-ending legal loop.

intro_text: Non prosequitur (also known as non pros.) is a legal judgment "against the plaintiff for a neglect to take any of those steps which it is incumbent on him to take in due time." A non pros judgment is a final judgment, which is only re-opened with cause shown.
story:
Non prosequitur, also known as non pros, is a legal term that means a judgment against the plaintiff for failing to take necessary steps in a timely manner. Essentially, it means that the plaintiff didn't do what they were supposed to do, and now they can't proceed with their case.

Story:

Meet Jane, a plaintiff who filed a lawsuit against a company for breaching her contract. She was excited to present her case in court and confident that she would win. However, Jane's lawyer informed her that she had neglected to serve the defendant with the necessary legal documents within the required time frame.

As a result, the court entered a non prosequitur judgment against Jane, effectively dismissing her case. Jane was devastated and didn't understand why this had happened. Her lawyer explained that she had missed a crucial step in the legal process, and now her case was over.

Jane asked if there was anything she could do to reopen her case, but her lawyer explained that a non pros judgment is final and can only be reopened if there is a valid reason. In this case, there wasn't any cause to show, and Jane's failure to follow the proper procedures had resulted in the dismissal of her case.

Jane was disappointed, but she learned a valuable lesson about the importance of following proper legal procedures. She realized that she couldn't take shortcuts or miss steps in the legal process, or she risked losing her case.

In the end, Jane decided to regroup and focus on other legal matters. She made sure to carefully follow all the necessary steps and procedures in her future cases, ensuring that she wouldn't make the same mistake again.

The story of Jane illustrates the concept of non prosequitur, which is a judgment against a plaintiff for failing to take the necessary steps in a legal case. It highlights the importance of following proper legal procedures and the consequences of neglecting to do so.

intro_text:
In law, nonacquiescence is the intentional failure by one branch of the government to comply with the decision of another to some degree. intro_text:
The doctrine of nondelegation (or non-delegation principle) is the theory that one branch of government must not authorize another entity to exercise the power or function which it is constitutionally authorized to exercise itself. It is explicit or implicit in all written constitutions that impose a strict structural separation of powers. It is usually applied in questions of constitutionally improper delegations of powers of any of the three branches of government to either of the other, to the administrative state, or to private entities. Although it is usually constitutional for executive officials to delegate executive powers to executive branch subordinates, there can also be improper delegations of powers within an executive branch.
In the United Kingdom, the non-delegation principle refers to the prima facie presumption that statutory powers granted to public bodies by Parliament can not be delegated to other people or bodies.
story:
The nondelegation doctrine is a principle that states that one branch of government cannot give its power or responsibilities to another branch or entity. This means that each branch of government must exercise the powers and functions that are constitutionally granted to it, and cannot transfer them to another branch or entity.

For example, the legislative branch (Congress) cannot give its power to make laws to the executive branch (the President), or to a private company. Similarly, the executive branch cannot give its power to enforce laws to the judicial branch (the courts), or to a private citizen.

This principle is based on the idea of separation of powers, which is a fundamental principle of constitutional government. This means that each branch of government has its own specific responsibilities and powers, and that no one branch should have too much power or control over the others.

In the United Kingdom, this principle is also known as the non-delegation principle, and it applies to public bodies that are granted powers by Parliament. These public bodies cannot delegate their powers to other people or bodies, unless they are explicitly allowed to do so by law.

In summary, the nondelegation doctrine is a principle that ensures that each branch of government exercises its own powers and responsibilities, and that no one branch has too much power or control over the others. It helps to maintain the balance of power and the separation of powers, which are essential for a healthy and functioning democracy.

intro_text: Nulla poena sine culpa (Latin for "no punishment without fault" or "no punishment without culpability") or the guilt principle is a legal principle requiring that one cannot be punished for something that they are not guilty of. It is recognized as a human right by the Court of Justice of the European Union and all Council of Europe member states. Under this principle, a person can not be punished if he or she is not guilty. Cases of force majeure or necessity are exempted from criminal responsibility. Furthermore, it establishes that no one can be liable for the crimes committed by another person.
story:

It's a human right recognized by the Court of Justice of the European Union and all Council of Europe member states. This principle ensures that individuals are not held criminally responsible for acts they did not commit, and they cannot be held liable for crimes committed by someone else.

The principle of Nulla poena sine culpa ensures that individuals are not punished for something they did not do and are not held responsible for the actions of others.

intro_text: The Nuremberg principles are a set of guidelines for determining what constitutes a war crime. The document was created by the International Law Commission of the United Nations to codify the legal principles underlying the Nuremberg Trials of Nazi party members following World War II.
story:
The Nuremberg Principles are a set of rules that help determine what is considered a war crime. These rules were created by the United Nations to guide the Nuremberg Trials, which were held after World War II to prosecute Nazi party members for their role in the war.

Story:

Imagine you are a young lawyer who has just started working at an international law firm. One day, your boss assigns you to work on a case involving war crimes committed during a recent conflict. As you dive into your research, you quickly realize that the concept of war crimes can be quite complex. There are many different laws and regulations that govern war, and it can be difficult to determine what is considered a violation. That's where the Nuremberg Principles come in.

The Nuremberg Principles were created after World War II to provide a framework for prosecuting those responsible for war crimes. The principles were developed by the International Law Commission of the United Nations and were used to guide the Nuremberg Trials, which were held to prosecute Nazi party members for their role in the war.

The principles are based on several key concepts. First, they establish that any person who commits a war crime is responsible for their actions, regardless of their military rank or position. This means that soldiers, commanders, and even heads of state can be held accountable for their actions during war.

Second, the principles establish that certain acts are considered war crimes, including murder, torture, and the use of poison gas. These acts are considered violations of the laws and customs of war and are punishable under international law.

Third, the principles establish that any person who commits a war crime can be prosecuted, regardless of their nationality. This means that individuals from any country can be held accountable for their actions during war, regardless of where the crime was committed.

Finally, the principles establish that any person who commits a war crime can be tried in an international court of law. This means that individuals who commit war crimes can be prosecuted in a court of law, regardless of where the crime was committed.

As you continue your research, you begin to understand how the Nuremberg Principles can be applied to the case you are working on. You realize that the principles provide a clear framework for determining what constitutes a war crime and how to prosecute those responsible.

intro_text: Obiter dictum (usually used in the plural, obiter dicta) is a Latin phrase meaning "other things said", that is, a remark in a legal opinion that is "said in passing" by any judge or arbitrator. It is a concept derived from English common law, whereby a judgment comprises only two elements: ratio decidendi and obiter dicta. For the purposes of judicial precedent, ratio decidendi is binding, whereas obiter dicta are persuasive only.
story:
Obiter dictum refers to additional comments or remarks made by a judge or arbitrator in a legal opinion that are not necessary to the decision of the case. These comments are not binding and are only persuasive, meaning they can influence future court decisions but are not considered a legal precedent.

Story:

Imagine you are a legal assistant working on a case involving a car accident. The judge has just delivered the verdict, and your boss, the lawyer, is reviewing the document. As you read through the judgment, you notice that the judge has included some additional comments that seem interesting but are not directly related to the case at hand.

You ask your boss about these comments and he explains that they are obiter dicta, or "other things said." He tells you that these comments are not binding and are only persuasive, meaning they can influence future court decisions but are not considered a legal precedent.

To illustrate this point, your boss gives you an example. He tells you that in a previous case, a judge made a comment about the importance of wearing seatbelts while driving. While this comment was not directly related to the case, it can still be used as persuasive evidence in future cases involving car accidents.

You start to understand the concept of obiter dicta and how it can be useful in legal cases. You realize that judges and arbitrators often include these additional comments to provide context or offer guidance for future cases, even though they are not legally binding.

As you continue to work on the case, you notice that the judge has included several other obiter dicta throughout the judgment. Your boss asks you to review them and provide a summary of what they say.

After reviewing the comments, you realize that they cover a range of topics, from the importance of following traffic laws to the impact of road conditions on car accidents. While these comments are not legally binding, they provide valuable insights into the judge's thinking and can be useful in future cases.

You feel proud that you now understand the concept of obiter dicta and can apply it in your work as a legal assistant. You realize that these additional comments may seem minor, but they can have a significant impact on how judges and lawyers approach legal cases in the future.

intro_text: In international law, odious debt, also known as illegitimate debt, is a legal theory that says that the national debt incurred by a despotic regime should not be enforceable. Such debts are, thus, considered by this doctrine to be personal debts of the regime that incurred them and not debts of the state. In some respects, the concept is analogous to the invalidity of contracts signed under coercion. Whether or not it is possible to discharge debts in this manner is a matter of dispute.
story:
Odious debt refers to the idea that a country's national debt should not be enforced if it was incurred by a corrupt or oppressive government. This theory suggests that the debt is not the responsibility of the people, but rather the personal debt of the regime that incurred it. This is similar to the idea that contracts signed under coercion are not valid. The concept of odious debt is controversial, and it is not clear whether it is possible to cancel debts in this way.

Story:

Once upon a time, in a small country called Verdania, a corrupt government came to power. This government, led by a dictator named President Cortez, was known for its human rights abuses, corruption, and embezzlement. The government borrowed large sums of money from foreign banks and institutions to finance its lavish spending and oppressive policies.

The people of Verdania suffered greatly under President Cortez's rule. They lived in poverty, and their basic human rights were constantly violated. The country's economy was in shambles, and the national debt continued to grow.

After several years of suffering, the people of Verdania finally rose up and overthrew President Cortez's regime. A new government was formed, and it began to investigate the debts incurred by the previous regime. The new government discovered that much of the debt was odious, meaning it was incurred for personal gain by President Cortez and his allies, rather than for the benefit of the people.

The new government decided to challenge the odious debt in court. They argued that the debt was not the responsibility of the people, but rather the personal debt of President Cortez and his regime. The court agreed, and the debt was declared invalid.

The people of Verdania were overjoyed. They finally had a chance to rebuild their country without the burden of the odious debt. The new government was able to invest in education, healthcare, and infrastructure, and the economy began to flourish.

However, the foreign banks and institutions that had lent money to President Cortez's regime were not happy with the court's decision. They argued that they had acted in good faith and should not be held responsible for the corrupt actions of the previous regime.

The case went all the way to the international court, where the judges had to decide whether the odious debt was truly the personal debt of President Cortez and his regime, or whether it was the responsibility of the people of Verdania.

After much deliberation, the court ruled in favor of the people of Verdania. They declared that the odious debt was not enforceable, and that the people of Verdania were not responsible for paying it back.

The people of Verdania celebrated their victory, and the country was finally able to move forward, free from the burden of the odious debt. The case set a precedent for other countries facing similar situations, and it marked a significant step forward in the fight against corruption and oppression.

In conclusion, the concept of odious debt is an important one in international law. It recognizes that the national debt incurred by a corrupt or oppressive government should not be the responsibility of the people. The story of Verdania illustrates how the concept of odious debt can be used to challenge unjust debts and give people a chance to rebuild their countries without the burden of corruption and oppression.

intro_text: The open court principle requires that court proceedings presumptively be open and accessible to the public and to the media.In contrast, in camera describes court proceedings where the public and press are not allowed to observe the procedure or process.
story:
The open court principle is the idea that court cases should be open to the public and media, while in camera proceedings are closed to the public and media.

Imagine you're a curious citizen who wants to observe a court case. You show up to the courthouse and take a seat in the gallery, ready to learn about the legal system in action. But, you're surprised to find out that the courtroom doors are closed, and you're not allowed to enter.

This is an example of an in camera proceeding, where the public and media are not allowed to observe the court case. In camera proceedings are typically used for cases that involve sensitive information, like a minor's privacy or national security.

Now, imagine you're a journalist who's been following a high-profile case. You've been reporting on the case for weeks, and your readers are eager to know what's happening in the courtroom. But, when you show up to the courthouse, you're told that the proceedings are in camera, and you can't report on anything that's happening inside.

This is frustrating, because you know that the public has a right to know what's happening in the courtroom. That's where the open court principle comes in. The open court principle is the idea that court proceedings should be open and accessible to the public and media, unless there's a good reason to keep them closed.

In an open court proceeding, anyone can come and observe the case, as long as they follow the court's rules and respect the participants. This means that journalists can report on the case, and the public can see justice in action.

So, why is the open court principle important? It's important because it promotes transparency and accountability in the legal system. When court proceedings are open, the public can see that justice is being served fairly and impartially. It also allows the media to report on cases, which helps to educate the public about the legal system and hold judges and lawyers accountable for their actions.

In summary, the open court principle is the idea that court proceedings should be open to the public and media, while in camera proceedings are closed to the public and media. The open court principle promotes transparency and accountability in the legal system, and it's important for ensuring that justice is served fairly and impartially.

limitation_question:

intro_text: The open-fields doctrine (also open-field doctrine or open-fields rule), in the U.S. law of criminal procedure, is the legal doctrine that a "warrantless search of the area outside a property owner's curtilage" does not violate the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution. However, "unless there is some other legal basis for the search," such a search "must exclude the home and any adjoining land (such as a yard) that is within an enclosure or otherwise protected from public scrutiny."
story:
The open-fields doctrine allows law enforcement to search open fields or areas outside a property without a warrant, as long as the area is not within a fenced-in yard or enclosure that is protected from public view.

Story:

Imagine you are a farmer who grows crops in a large open field. One day, the police receive a tip that someone in the area is growing illegal drugs. The police arrive at your farm and ask to search your fields. You tell them that you don't have any drugs and that they need a warrant to search your property.

The police explain that they don't need a warrant because of the open-fields doctrine. They tell you that since your fields are open and visible to the public, they are not considered private property and therefore can be searched without a warrant.

You are unsure about this and ask them to explain further. They explain that the open-fields doctrine was established by the courts to allow police to search areas that are open and accessible to the public, such as fields, without violating the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures.

They also explain that this doctrine does not apply to areas that are enclosed or protected from public view, such as a fenced-in yard or a barn. Those areas are considered private and would require a warrant to search.

You understand this and agree to let the police search your fields. They search the fields and find no drugs. You are relieved that the search was done without a warrant and that your privacy was respected.

In this scenario, the open-fields doctrine allowed the police to search the open fields without a warrant, but they still had to respect the privacy of any enclosed areas. This doctrine helps to balance the need for law enforcement to investigate crimes with the protection of individual privacy rights.

intro_text: Open justice is a legal principle that requires that judicial proceedings be conducted in a transparent manner and with the oversight of the people, so as to safeguard the rights of those subject to the power of the court and to allow for the scrutiny of the public in general. The term has particular emphasis in legal systems based on British law, such as in the United Kingdom, Commonwealth countries such as South Africa and Canada and Australia, and former British colonies such as the United States. The term has several closely related meanings: it is seen as a fundamental right guaranteeing liberty; it describes guidelines for how courts can be more transparent; and it sometimes identifies an ideal situation. In a courtroom, it means steps to promote transparency such as letting the public see and hear trials as they happen in real time, televising trials as they happen, videotaping proceedings for later viewing, publishing the content and documents of court files, providing transcripts of statements, making past decisions available for review in an easy-to-access format, publishing decisions, and giving reporters full access to files and participants so they can report what happens. The principle includes efforts to try to make what happens in the court understandable to the public and the press.In Canada, open justice is referred to as the open court principle.
story:
Open justice is the idea that court proceedings should be open and transparent to the public. This means that trials should be held in public, and that the public should have access to court documents and decisions. This helps to ensure that the court is accountable and that the rights of those involved in the case are protected.

Imagine you're a reporter covering a high-profile trial. You arrive at the courthouse and are greeted by a sign that says "Open Justice". You're not sure what this means, but you're eager to find out.

You take a seat in the gallery and watch as the lawyers present their arguments and the judge makes their decision.

After the trial, you're curious to learn more about the open justice principle. You do some research and discover that it's not just about letting the public watch trials. It's also about making sure that court documents and decisions are easily accessible to the public. This means that reporters like you can review court files and publish their findings, helping to ensure that the court is accountable to the public.

B) A legal principle that requires that judicial proceedings be conducted in a transparent manner, with the oversight of the people.

C) A legal principle that requires that judicial proceedings be conducted only in the presence of lawyers and judges, without any public access.

D) A legal principle that requires that judicial proceedings be conducted only in the presence of law enforcement officials, without any public access.

The right answer is B) A legal principle that requires that judicial proceedings be conducted in a transparent manner, with the oversight of the people.

Explanation: Open justice is a legal principle that emphasizes the importance of transparency and public oversight in judicial proceedings. It requires that trials be held in public, and that court documents and decisions be easily accessible to the public. This helps to promote trust and confidence in the legal system, and ensures that the court is accountable to the public. The other options are not accurate descriptions of the concept, as they either limit public access or exclude the public altogether.
ending_question:
Question: In a hypothetical scenario where a high-profile trial is being held, the principle of open justice is applied. The trial is being broadcasted live on television, and the public has access to court documents and decisions. Suddenly, new evidence is discovered that could potentially exonerate the defendant. How should the court proceed?

A) The court should immediately halt the trial and review the new evidence in private.
B) The court should continue with the trial, ignoring the new evidence, to avoid any further delays.
C) The court should allow the defense to present the new evidence in court, and the prosecution should also be given the opportunity to respond.
D) The court should dismiss the case altogether, citing a lack of evidence.

The right answer is C. The court should allow the defense to present the new evidence in court, and the prosecution should also be given the opportunity to respond. This is because the principle of open justice requires that the court be transparent and accountable to the public. By allowing both sides to present their arguments and evidence in court, the public can see that the court is following proper procedures and treating everyone equally. Additionally, this approach would help to ensure that justice is served and that the correct verdict is reached.
limitation_question:
Question: What is a potential limitation or exception of the rule "Open justice"?

A) The public's right to know supersedes individual privacy rights.
B) The court's duty to protect sensitive information outweighs the public's right to access.
C) The principle only applies to criminal trials, not civil cases.
D) The open justice principle is absolute and cannot be limited under any circumstances.

The right answer is B) The court's duty to protect sensitive information outweighs the public's right to access.

Explanation: While the open justice principle emphasizes transparency and public access, it is not absolute and can be limited in certain circumstances. One such limitation is when the court needs to protect sensitive information, such as national security secrets, personal privacy interests, or confidential business information. In such cases, the court may restrict public access to certain documents or proceedings to ensure that this information is not disclosed. This limitation is necessary to strike a balance between the public's right to know and the need to protect sensitive information. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

intro_text:
The open mines doctrine is a term of real property. Under the open mines doctrine, depletion of natural resources constitutes waste unless consumption of such resources constitutes normal use of the land, as in the case of a life estate in coal mine or a granite quarry. 
The life tenant cannot open the land to search for minerals and other natural resources, but if the quarries or mines were open before the tenant took the life estate, then it is not waste for the life tenant to continue their use.  Where the life tenant opens the land for new mines (i.e., voluntary waste) a remainderman can enjoin such.
The sale of harvestable crops does not constitute waste.
story:
The open mines doctrine is a legal principle that applies to the use of land with natural resources. It states that using up natural resources without permission is considered wasteful, unless it's a normal part of the land's use, like in the case of a coal mine or granite quarry.

Imagine you own a piece of land with a coal mine that has been in operation for years. You have a life estate in the land, which means you have the right to use it during your lifetime, but the land will eventually pass to someone else, known as the remainderman.

According to the open mines doctrine, it's not wasteful to continue operating the coal mine, as it's a normal part of the land's use. However, if you decide to open up new mines on the land, that would be considered wasteful, as it's not a normal part of the land's use. The remainderman has the right to stop you from doing this.

On the other hand, if you're growing crops on the land and harvesting them, that's not considered wasteful. It's a normal part of the land's use, and the remainderman can't stop you from doing it.

In summary, the open mines doctrine is a legal principle that aims to prevent the wasteful use of natural resources on land, especially when it comes to mining and extracting resources. It's important to understand this principle when dealing with land that has natural resources, to ensure that the land is used responsibly and sustainably.

intro_text: Pacta sunt servanda, Latin for "agreements must be kept", is a brocard and a fundamental principle of law. According to Hans Wehberg, a professor of international law, "few rules for the ordering of Society have such a deep moral and religious influence" as this principle.In its most common sense, the principle refers to private contracts and prescribes that the provisions, i.e. clauses, of a contract are law between the parties to the contract, and therefore implies that neglect of their respective obligations is a violation of the contract. The first known expression of the brocard is in the writings of the canonist Cardinal Hostiensis from the 13th century AD, which were published in the 16th.
story: Pacta sunt servanda, also known as "agreements must be kept," is a basic rule in law that means when people or organizations make a promise or agreement, they should keep it. This includes following the specific terms or requirements written in a contract. It's like a golden rule for keeping one's word and respecting agreements. Imagine you promised a friend you'd meet them at the park tomorrow at 2 PM, but then you suddenly change your mind and don't show up. Your friend would likely feel let down or upset because you didn't keep your word. Similarly, if someone signs a contract agreeing to do something, like pay back a loan or deliver goods by a certain date, they should follow through on those commitments. If they don't, it's considered a violation of the contract and could lead to legal consequences. In short, pacta sunt servanda emphasizes the importance of keeping promises and honoring agreements, whether it's between individuals or organizations.
concept_question:
Question: Which of the following accurately describes the concept "Pacta_sunt_servanda"?

B) A brocard that highlights the significance of maintaining promises and fulfilling contractual obligations.
C) A rule that requires all parties involved in a contract to fulfill their respective duties.
D) A provision that permits parties to breach a contract if it is deemed unfair.

The right answer is B) A brocard that highlights the significance of maintaining promises and fulfilling contractual obligations.

Explanation: Pacta sunt servanda is a fundamental principle of law that emphasizes the importance of keeping promises and honoring agreements. It applies to both written and verbal contracts, and it is not limited to private contracts but also includes public contracts and international treaties. The principle serves as a reminder that when individuals or organizations make a promise or agreement, they are expected to keep it, regardless of any circumstances that may arise later. Therefore, option B accurately describes the concept of Pacta sunt servanda.
ending_question:
Question: A company hires an employee under a signed contract with a non-compete clause. After a year, the employee leaves the company and starts a competing business. The company sues the employee for violating the non-compete clause. How does the principle of "Pacta sunt servanda" apply in this scenario?

A) The employee is not bound by the non-compete clause since it is unfair to restrict their ability to work in their field.
B) The employee is bound by the non-compete clause since it was agreed upon in the contract they signed.
C) The company has no right to sue the employee since they did not fulfill their obligations under the contract.
D) The court should consider the best interests of both parties and decide on a case-by-case basis.

The right answer is B) The employee is bound by the non-compete clause since it was agreed upon in the contract they signed.

Explanation: The principle of "Pacta sunt servanda" states that agreements must be kept, and contractual provisions are law between the parties. When the employee signed the contract with the non-compete clause, they agreed to abide by its terms. Leaving the company and starting a competing business violates the non-compete clause, which means the employee failed to keep their end of the agreement. Therefore, the company has the right to take legal action against the employee for breaching the contract.
limitation_question:

D) The rule does not apply to agreements made between minors or individuals with mental incapacity.

The right answer is B) The rule does not apply to agreements made under duress or coercion.

This is because the party did not truly consent to the terms of the agreement, and therefore, the agreement is not binding.

intro_text: Paraphrasing of copyrighted material may, under certain circumstances, constitute copyright infringement. In most countries that have national copyright laws, copyright applies to the original expression in a work rather than to the meanings or ideas being expressed. Whether a paraphrase is an infringement of expression, or a permissible restatement of an idea, is not a binary question but a matter of degree. Copyright law in common law countries tries to avoid theoretical discussion of the nature of ideas and expression such as this, taking a more pragmatic view of what is called the idea/expression dichotomy. The acceptable degree of difference between a prior work and a paraphrase depends on a variety of factors and ultimately depends on the judgement of the court in each individual case.
story:
Imagine you're a writer, and you want to use some ideas from another writer's work in your own writing. You're not sure if this is allowed, and you don't want to get sued for copyright infringement.

Here's the thing: copyright law protects the way ideas are expressed, not the ideas themselves. So, if you take someone else's words and change them a bit, it's still considered copyright infringement.

But, if you take the ideas from the original work and express them in your own unique way, it's not considered infringement. It's like taking a recipe and changing some of the ingredients - it's still the same dish, but with your own twist.

The problem is, it's not always clear how much you can change someone else's work before it becomes copyright infringement. It's not a black and white issue, it's more like a gray area.

That's why courts have to decide on a case-by-case basis whether a paraphrase is an infringement or not. They look at things like how much of the original work was used, how different the paraphrase is from the original, and whether the paraphrase is still recognizable as coming from the original work.

So, as a writer, you need to be careful when using ideas from other people's work. Make sure you're not copying their exact words, and try to add your own unique spin to the ideas. That way, you can avoid getting into legal trouble and still create something new and interesting.

intro_text: The Parker immunity doctrine is an exemption from liability for engaging in antitrust violations.  It applies to the state when it exercises legislative authority in creating a regulation with anticompetitive effects, and to private actors when they act at the direction of the state after it has done so.  The doctrine is named for the Supreme Court of the United States case in which it was initially developed, Parker v. Brown.The rationale behind Parker immunity is that Congress, in enacting the Sherman Act, evidenced no intent to restrain state behavior.
story:
The Parker immunity doctrine protects states and private actors from being sued for antitrust violations when they are following state regulations that have anticompetitive effects. This means that if a state passes a law that limits competition, the state and private actors who follow the law cannot be held liable for violating antitrust laws.

Imagine you are a farmer who wants to sell your crops at a farmer's market. The state passes a law that says farmers can only sell their crops at a certain price, which is lower than what you would normally charge. You follow the law and sell your crops at the lower price, but another farmer sues you for violating antitrust laws by agreeing to sell at a lower price.

In this scenario, the Parker immunity doctrine would protect you from being liable for antitrust violations because you were simply following a state regulation. The doctrine recognizes that the state has the authority to regulate commerce within its borders, and it does not want to interfere with that authority.

The doctrine is named after a Supreme Court case called Parker v. Brown, in which the court first established this principle. The court ruled that Congress did not intend to restrict state regulation of commerce when it passed the Sherman Act, which is the main antitrust law in the United States. Therefore, states and private actors who follow state regulations are immune from antitrust liability.

It's important to note that the Parker immunity doctrine is not absolute and has some limitations. For example, if a state regulation is clearly anticompetitive and has no legitimate purpose, it may not be protected by the doctrine. Additionally, private actors who act independently and not at the direction of the state may not be protected by the doctrine.

In summary, the Parker immunity doctrine protects states and private actors from antitrust liability when they follow state regulations that have anticompetitive effects. It recognizes the authority of states to regulate commerce within their borders and ensures that they are not held liable for simply following the law.

intro_text: The parol evidence rule is a rule in the Anglo-American common law that governs what kinds of evidence parties to a contract dispute can introduce when trying to determine the specific terms of a contract. The rule also prevents parties who have reduced their agreement to a final written document from later introducing other evidence, such as the content of oral discussions from earlier in the negotiation process, as evidence of a different intent as to the terms of the contract.  The rule provides that "extrinsic evidence is inadmissible to vary a written contract". The term "parol" derives from the Anglo-Norman French parol or parole, meaning "word of mouth" or "verbal", and in medieval times referred to oral pleadings in a court case.The rule's  origins lie in English contract law, but it has been adopted in other common law jurisdictions; however there are now some differences between application of the rule in different jurisdictions. For instance, in the US, a common misconception is that it is a rule of evidence (like the Federal Rules of Evidence), but that is not the case; whereas in England it is indeed a rule of evidence.The supporting rationale for excluding the content of verbal agreements from written contracts is that since the contracting parties have agreed to reduce their contract to a single and final writing, extrinsic evidence of past agreements or terms should not be considered when interpreting that writing, as the parties ultimately decided to leave them out of the contract. In other words, one may not use evidence made prior to the written contract to contradict the writing.
story:
The parol evidence rule is a legal principle that restricts the use of extrinsic evidence to alter the terms of a written contract. It states that when parties have agreed to a final written document, they cannot introduce other evidence, such as oral discussions from earlier negotiations, to contradict the written agreement. This rule aims to prevent parties from claiming different intentions or terms than what is written in the contract.

Imagine you and your friend, John, are making a deal. You both agree to buy a car from each other, and you put the agreement in writing. The contract states that the car's price is $10,000, and John will deliver it to you next week. Later, John claims that he remembers you both agreeing the price would be $12,000, and that he would deliver the car the following week. In court, John cannot use his oral agreement as evidence to contradict the written contract. This is because the parol evidence rule prohibits using extrinsic evidence to vary a written contract.

The rule has its roots in English contract law and has been adopted in other common law jurisdictions, but there are variations in its application. Some people mistakenly believe it is a rule of evidence, like the Federal Rules of Evidence, but it is not. The reasoning behind this rule is that when parties agree to reduce their contract to a single, final writing, they should not be able to use previous agreements or terms as evidence to contradict the written contract. In other words, what is written in the contract is what matters, and prior agreements or discussions cannot be used to change its meaning.

In summary, the parol evidence rule prevents parties from introducing extrinsic evidence to alter the terms of a written contract. It ensures that the written agreement is the final and binding version of the contract, and that parties cannot contradict it with prior oral agreements or discussions.

intro_text:
A peremptory norm (also called jus cogens) is a fundamental principle of international law that is accepted by the international community of states as a norm from which no derogation is permitted.
There is no universal agreement regarding precisely which norms are jus cogens nor how a norm reaches that status, but it is generally accepted that jus cogens bans genocide, maritime piracy, enslaving in general (i.e. slavery as well as slave trade), wars of aggression and territorial aggrandizement, torture, and refoulement.  The latter two are evolving and controversial as they rest mainly on the definition of torture in regards to criminal sentencing. If sentencing is not cruel, inhuman or degrading but arbitrary or disproportionate convictions are imposed then a state's refoulement  where limited to the returning of unsubstantiated asylum claimants  may still be lawfully conducted to many such countries which are juridically developing, such as those lacking a clear separation of powers, with a relatively heightened risk of political persecution and reports of unfair trials.
story:
A peremptory norm, also known as jus cogens, is a fundamental principle of international law that cannot be ignored or violated by any country. It's like a rule that everyone agrees on and cannot be changed. There are a few principles that are generally accepted as peremptory norms, such as banning genocide, slavery, and wars of aggression. However, there is no clear agreement on how a norm becomes a peremptory norm or exactly which norms should be included.

Imagine a group of friends who all agree on a set of rules for playing a game together. They can't just change the rules whenever they want, because they've all agreed to follow them. If one of the friends tries to break the rules, the others can call them out on it and refuse to play with them until they start following the rules again.

In the same way, countries agree to follow peremptory norms of international law. If a country breaks one of these norms, other countries can condemn their actions and may even refuse to cooperate with them until they start following the rules again.

Now, there are some controversial issues, like the definition of torture, that can make it difficult to determine whether a country is following the rules or not. It's like if one of the friends in the game group thought it was okay to cheat a little bit, but the others didn't agree. In cases like this, it's important for countries to have open and honest discussions about what the rules should be and how they should be followed.

Overall, peremptory norms are important because they provide a clear set of guidelines for countries to follow, and help to ensure that everyone is treated fairly and with respect for their human rights.

intro_text: The physical proximity doctrine is a standard in criminal law for distinguishing between preparation and attempt.:683 "Physical" refers to the physical element of a criminal act (actus reus), as distinguished from the mental element of a guilty mind (mens rea). When a person makes preparation to commit a crime, and one of the preparatory acts is close or proximate to the completed crime, the preparation is considered to have merged into being an actual attempt.:683 The standard is not a clear bright line standard.:683 The closer the preparatory act is to the completed crime, the stronger the case for calling it an attempt.:683 The determination as to whether the standard has been met is a matter for the jury to determine.
story:
The physical proximity doctrine is a legal principle used to determine when preparation for a crime becomes an actual attempt. It states that if a person takes a physical step towards committing a crime, and that step is close to the final act of the crime, then it can be considered an attempt rather than just preparation.

For example, imagine a person who plans to rob a bank. They drive to the bank, put on a ski mask, and take out a gun. They approach the entrance of the bank, but then change their mind and leave. In this scenario, the person has taken several physical steps towards committing the crime, such as driving to the bank, putting on a ski mask, and taking out a gun. However, they did not actually enter the bank or attempt to rob it.

In this case, the physical proximity doctrine would come into play. The question would be whether the person's preparatory acts, such as driving to the bank and putting on a ski mask, are close enough to the final act of the crime, which would be entering the bank and robbing it. If the jury determines that these acts are close enough, then they could consider it an attempt to commit a crime, rather than just preparation.

It's important to note that the physical proximity doctrine is not a clear-cut standard, and the determination of whether an act is considered an attempt or preparation will depend on the specific circumstances of the case and the jury's interpretation. The doctrine is meant to provide guidance in cases where it's not clear whether a person has crossed the line from preparation to attempt.
