intro_text:
The murders of Haile Kifer and Nicholas Brady occurred on Thanksgiving Day of 2012, when Haile Kifer, 18, and her cousin, Nicholas Brady, 17, broke into the home of 64-year-old Byron David Smith in Little Falls, Minnesota, in the United States. Smith shot the teens separately and 10 minutes apart as they entered the basement where he was, later stating to police he was worried about them being armed. After already shooting them once, he repeatedly taunted them while they were injured as he shot them both in an execution style until they were dead. He did not report that he had killed Kifer and Brady until the day after the murders, keeping their corpses in his closet. On April 29, 2014, he was found guilty of two counts of premeditated first-degree murder. He was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.
The case sparked debate over the "castle doctrine", which allows homeowners to defend their homes with lethal force. The prosecution alleged that Smith's actions and a recording he made himself while the incidents were unfolding showed premeditation (lying in wait) and that he used excessive force after having neutralized the threat. He was convicted by a jury after three hours of deliberation and sentenced to life in prison.
story:

You go to check it out, and you find two teenagers, Haile Kifer and Nicholas Brady, who have broken into your home. They're unarmed, but you're worried they might harm you or your family.

You have a choice to make. You can either try to call the police and wait for them to arrive, or you can take matters into your own hands and defend yourself. In this situation, Byron David Smith, the homeowner, chose to defend himself. He shot the teens, killing them both.

But here's the thing - Smith didn't just shoot them in self-defense. He shot them multiple times, even after they were already injured and posed no threat to him. He also taunted them while they were dying, which is just horrible.

The case went to trial, and the prosecution argued that Smith's actions were premeditated and excessive. They said he had planned to kill the teens and used way more force than he needed to. The jury agreed, and Smith was found guilty of two counts of first-degree murder. He's now serving life in prison without the possibility of parole.

This case raises questions about the "castle doctrine," which allows homeowners to defend their homes with lethal force. It's important to remember that even if you feel threatened, you shouldn't use more force than necessary to protect yourself. intro_text:
The spider in the web doctrine is a legal doctrine in Dutch patent law governing cross-border injunctions in patent infringement cases.  Under this doctrine, the Dutch courts would assume jurisdiction only in cases where the main defendant (the "spider") was located in the Netherlands and where the other defendants were part of a group of companies and acted based on a common business policy of this group (the "web"), regardless of the nation in which the disputed patent was issued.
Decisions by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) have cast some doubt on the continuing validity of this doctrine.  This is due in part to the fact that the ECJ did not feel that Dutch courts were competent to make predictions or judgments about the validity of patents granted outside the Netherlands, preferring to grant jurisdiction to the countries in which the patent was granted.

The spider in the web doctrine is a legal principle in Dutch patent law that governs cross-border injunctions in patent infringement cases. It states that Dutch courts will only have jurisdiction over a patent infringement case if the main defendant (the "spider") is located in the Netherlands and the other defendants (the "web") are part of a group of companies with a common business policy. This doctrine is limited by the European Court of Justice, which prefers to grant jurisdiction to the countries where the patent was granted, rather than the Netherlands.

Story:

Once upon a time, a clever spider named Alex lived in a cozy web in the Netherlands. Alex was the CEO of a global company that produced high-quality patented webs. The company had several subsidiaries around the world, all of which followed Alex's business policies.

One day, a competitor named Ben, who was also a spider, began to produce and sell identical webs, infringing on Alex's patent. Ben's company was based in Germany, but he had several subsidiaries in other countries, including the Netherlands.

Alex decided to take legal action against Ben and his subsidiaries. He went to the Dutch courts, citing the spider in the web doctrine. He argued that since he, the main defendant, was located in the Netherlands, and the other defendants were part of a group of companies with a common business policy, the Dutch courts had jurisdiction over the case.

The Dutch courts agreed with Alex and granted an injunction, ordering Ben and his subsidiaries to stop producing and selling the infringing webs. Ben appealed the decision to the European Court of Justice, arguing that the Dutch courts did not have jurisdiction over the case.

The ECJ heard the case and ruled that the spider in the web doctrine was not valid. They stated that the Dutch courts were not competent to make judgments about the validity of patents granted outside the Netherlands. Instead, the ECJ granted jurisdiction to the countries where the patent was granted, in this case, Germany.

Alex was disappointed with the ECJ's decision, but he understood that the law must evolve to ensure fairness and consistency across national borders. He decided to pursue legal action in Germany, where he knew the courts would have jurisdiction over the case.

In the end, Alex's persistence paid off. The German courts ruled in his favor, and Ben was ordered to stop producing and selling the infringing webs. Alex's company continued to thrive, and he remained the master of his web empire.

The story of Alex and Ben illustrates the complexities of cross-border patent infringement cases and the importance of understanding the legal principles that govern them. The spider in the web doctrine may have been limited by the ECJ, but it remains an important part of the legal landscape, reminding us that the law must adapt to the changing needs of a globalized world.

intro_text: Spring and Autumn Courts () were an ancient Chinese judicial system, in which judges judge how to convict a case based on the ideas of righteousness of the Spring and Autumn Annals. The Spring and Autumn Courts began in the reign of Emperor Wu of Han and continued until the Tang dynasty when Confucianism and Jurisprudence merged to create the "unity of ritual and law".
story:
Spring and Autumn Courts were a way for judges to make decisions in ancient China. They looked at the facts of a case and used ideas from a book called the Spring and Autumn Annals to decide if someone was guilty or not guilty. This system started during the Han dynasty and lasted until the Tang dynasty when other ideas like Confucianism and Jurisprudence became more important.

Story:

Once upon a time, in ancient China, there was a kind and wise judge named Judge Li. He had been appointed to oversee a case involving a farmer named Zhang, who had been accused of stealing a horse from a wealthy landowner.

As Judge Li reviewed the case, he realized that the facts were not clear-cut. Zhang claimed that he had found the horse wandering in the fields and had taken it in to care for it, not realizing it belonged to someone else. The landowner, on the other hand, insisted that Zhang had stolen the horse to sell it for profit.

Judge Li knew that he had to make a difficult decision, but he also knew that he had to follow the principles of the Spring and Autumn Annals, which emphasized the importance of righteousness and fairness.

He decided to call upon the village elders and other respected members of the community to help him deliberate. Together, they poured over the details of the case, considering all the evidence and arguments presented by both sides.

After much discussion and debate, Judge Li made his decision. He ruled that Zhang was not guilty of theft, as he had not intended to steal the horse and had taken it in with good intentions. However, he also ordered Zhang to return the horse to its rightful owner and to pay a fine for his carelessness.

The landowner was not pleased with the decision, but he respected the judgment of Judge Li and the Spring and Autumn Courts. Zhang, on the other hand, was grateful for the fairness of the system and vowed to be more mindful in the future.

As news of Judge Li's decision spread, the people of the village praised the Spring and Autumn Courts for their wisdom and justice. The system continued to be used for many years, ensuring that the people of China were treated fairly and that justice was served.

In the end, the story of Judge Li and the Spring and Autumn Courts demonstrated the power of a fair and impartial judicial system, and the importance of considering all perspectives in the pursuit of justice.

intro_text: Staatenverbund  is a neologism for a system of multi-level governance in which states work more closely together than in a confederation but, unlike a federal state, retain their own sovereignty. The concept is used in Germany to describe the European Union but has no direct equivalent in other languages. In German jurisprudence, a Staatenverbund is a supranational institution that may exercise sovereign acts (laws, coin money, etc.) but may not independently fix areas where it may exercise this power.
story:
Staatenverbund refers to a system of governance where states collaborate closely while maintaining their independence. Imagine a group project where students work together but still have control over their individual tasks. Similarly, in a Staatenverbund, states share power but don't completely surrender their sovereignty.

In Germany, the term describes the European Union, where member states cooperate on various matters but still have their own governments and laws. It's like a club where members work together on specific projects but still have their own rules and decision-making power.

In legal terms, a Staatenverbund is an institution that can perform tasks that would normally require sovereign power, such as making laws or creating currency. However, it can't unilaterally decide what areas it has authority over. It's similar to a group of friends who agree to work together on a project but still have their own areas of expertise and decision-making power.

To summarize, a Staatenverbund is a system where states collaborate while maintaining their independence, similar to a group project where individuals work together but still have control over their parts. It's a way for states to cooperate without completely giving up their sovereignty.

intro_text:
Stadtluft macht frei ("urban air makes you free"), or Stadtluft macht frei nach Jahr und Tag ("city air makes you free after a year and a day"), is a German saying describing a principle of law in the Middle Ages. The period of a year and a day was a conventional period widely employed in Europe to represent a significant amount of time.  
From the 11th century onwards, liberated serfs and other members of the Third Estate founded settlements alongside the old Roman or Germanic ones. It was customary law that a city resident was free after one year and one day. After this he could no longer be reclaimed by his employer and thus became bound to the city. Serfs could flee the feudal lands and gain freedom in this way, making cities a territory outside the feudal system to a certain extent. This created the conditions for the revolts such as the Mnster Rebellion.
With the Statutum in favorem principum ("Statute in Favor of the Princes"), this regulation of customary law was officially abolished for the Holy Roman Empire in 1231/32. According to the statute, cities under royal jurisdiction were forbidden to protect serfs originally owned by the regional princes or their vassals. The statute is an example of power devolving from Imperial authority to that of territorial magnates during the drawn-out contest between the Hohenstaufen emperors and the Papacy.
The medieval concept of liberty was largely confined to traditional collective rights and privileges based in custom and precedent and often expressed in territorial liberties such as, to take English examples, the Liberties of the Tower of London or the Liberties of the Savoy. Historically, the development of individualism is a product of the ideology of liberalism, whose emphasis on modern individual liberties and freedom emerged in opposition to authoritarian oppression, in England culminating in the Glorious Revolution of 1688, and in France surfacing during the French Revolution.

This meant that serfs could escape their feudal lords and gain freedom by moving to a city. Cities were seen as a territory outside of the feudal system, and this law created the conditions for revolts such as the Mnster Rebellion.

In 1231/32, the Statutum in favorem principum, or Statute in Favor of the Princes, abolished this law for the Holy Roman Empire. The statute stated that cities under royal jurisdiction could not protect serfs who originally belonged to regional princes or their vassals. This shifted power from the Imperial authority to the territorial magnates during a time of conflict between the Hohenstaufen emperors and the Papacy.

The concept of liberty in the Middle Ages was based on traditional collective rights and privileges, often expressed in territorial liberties such as the Liberties of the Tower of London or the Liberties of the Savoy. The development of individualism and modern individual liberties and freedom emerged later, in opposition to authoritarian oppression, culminating in the Glorious Revolution of 1688 in England and the French Revolution in France.

intro_text:
A stand-your-ground law, sometimes called a "line in the sand" or "no duty to retreat" law, provides that people may use deadly force when they reasonably believe it to be necessary to defend against certain violent crimes (right of self-defense). Under such a law, people have no duty to retreat before using deadly force in self-defense, so long as they are in a place where they are lawfully present. The exact details vary by jurisdiction.
The alternative to stand your ground is "duty to retreat". In jurisdictions that implement a duty to retreat, even a person who is unlawfully attacked (or who is defending someone who is unlawfully attacked) may not use deadly force if it is possible to instead avoid the danger with complete safety by retreating.
Even areas that impose a duty to retreat generally follow the "castle doctrine", under which people have no duty to retreat when they are attacked in their homes, or (in some places) in their vehicles or workplaces.  The castle doctrine and "stand-your-ground" laws provide legal defenses to persons who have been charged with various use-of-force crimes against persons, such as murder, manslaughter, aggravated assault, and illegal discharge or brandishing of weapons, as well as attempts to commit such crimes.Whether a jurisdiction follows stand-your-ground or duty-to-retreat is just one element of its self-defense laws.  Different jurisdictions allow deadly force against different crimes.  All American states allow it against deadly force, great bodily injury, and likely kidnapping or rape; some also allow it against threat of robbery and burglary.
A 2020 RAND Corporation review of existing research concluded: "There is supportive evidence that stand-your-ground laws are associated with increases in firearm homicides and moderate evidence that they increase the total number of homicides."
story:
Stand-your-ground law allows individuals to use deadly force in self-defense when they reasonably believe it's necessary to prevent harm or death, without the requirement to retreat first. This law applies when an individual is in a place they are legally present, such as their home or workplace. The alternative is a duty-to-retreat law, which requires individuals to avoid danger by retreating before using deadly force. Stand-your-ground laws provide legal defense for individuals charged with use-of-force crimes, such as murder or aggravated assault. The law varies by jurisdiction, with some states allowing deadly force against different crimes like robbery or burglary. Research suggests that stand-your-ground laws may increase firearm homicides and total number of homicides.

Story: Imagine you are at home one evening when you hear a noise coming from outside. You look out the window and see a person lurking in the shadows. Suddenly, they break into your home through a window. You are in a place where you are legally present, and you reasonably believe that you and your family are in imminent danger of harm or death.

In a jurisdiction with a duty-to-retreat law, you would be required to try to escape the situation or retreat to a safe location before using deadly force in self-defense. However, in a jurisdiction with a stand-your-ground law, you have no duty to retreat and can use deadly force immediately to protect yourself and your family.

Suppose you have a gun and decide to confront the intruder. You shout a warning, but the intruder advances towards you. You reasonably believe that you are in imminent danger of death or great bodily harm, so you use your gun to defend yourself and your family.

In this scenario, if you are in a jurisdiction with a stand-your-ground law, you would have a legal defense for using deadly force in self-defense, as long as you were in a place where you were legally present and reasonably believed that deadly force was necessary to prevent harm or death. However, if you were in a jurisdiction with a duty-to-retreat law, you would be required to try to retreat or escape the situation before using deadly force, even if it means putting yourself and your family at greater risk.

It's important to note that stand-your-ground laws are not a license to use deadly force recklessly or in situations where it's not reasonably necessary. The law still requires that the use of deadly force be proportionate to the threat posed, and individuals who use deadly force in self-defense must still be able to articulate a reasonable belief that it was necessary to prevent harm or death.

In summary, stand-your-ground laws provide individuals with greater flexibility in defending themselves and their families in dangerous situations, but they must still act reasonably and proportionately to the threat posed. It's essential to understand the specific laws in your jurisdiction and to use good judgment in any situation where deadly force may be necessary.

intro_text:
In tort law, the standard of care is the only degree of prudence and caution required of an individual who is under a duty of care.
The requirements of the standard are closely dependent on circumstances. Whether the standard of care has been breached is determined by the trier of fact, and is usually phrased in terms of the reasonable person; this is sometimes labeled as the "reasonable physician standard." It was famously described in Vaughn v. Menlove (1837) as whether the individual "proceed[ed] with such reasonable caution as a prudent man would have exercised under such circumstances".
story:
The standard of care is a legal concept that refers to the level of caution and prudence that an individual or professional must exercise in their actions or decisions to avoid causing harm to others. In other words, it's the minimum level of care that a reasonable person would be expected to show in a given situation.

Imagine you're a doctor, and your patient has a serious illness. You have a duty of care to your patient, which means you must act with the level of skill and caution that a reasonably prudent doctor would use in the same situation. If you fail to meet this standard, you could be held liable for any harm that results.

The standard of care is not a fixed standard, but rather one that depends on the specific circumstances of each case. For example, the standard of care for a doctor treating a patient in a life-threatening emergency situation may be different from the standard of care for a doctor performing a routine check-up.

In court, it's up to the trier of fact (usually a judge or jury) to decide whether the standard of care has been breached. They will consider whether the individual or professional acted with the level of caution and prudence that a reasonable person would have exercised in the same situation. This is sometimes referred to as the "reasonable person standard" or the "reasonable physician standard" in medical cases.

The concept of standard of care is important because it helps to establish whether someone has been negligent or not. If an individual or professional has not met the standard of care, they may be liable for any harm that results. On the other hand, if they have met the standard of care, they are less likely to be held liable.

In summary, the standard of care is the minimum level of caution and prudence that an individual or professional must exercise in their actions or decisions to avoid causing harm to others. It's a flexible standard that depends on the specific circumstances of each case, and it's up to the trier of fact to decide whether the standard has been breached.

intro_text:
In law, standing or locus standi is a condition that a party seeking a legal remedy must show they have, by demonstrating to the court, sufficient connection to and harm from the law or action challenged to support that party's participation in the case. A party has standing in the following situations:

The party is directly subject to an adverse effect by the statute or action in question, and the harm suffered will continue unless the court grants relief in the form of damages or a finding that the law either does not apply to the party or that the law is void or can be nullified. In informal terms, a party must have something to lose.  The party has standing because they will be directly harmed by the conditions for which they are asking the court for relief.
The party is not directly harmed by the conditions by which they are petitioning the court for relief but asks for it because the harm involved has some reasonable relation to their situation, and the continued existence of the harm may affect others who might not be able to ask a court for relief. In the United States, this is the grounds for asking for a law to be struck down as violating the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, because while the plaintiff might not be directly affected, the law might so adversely affect others that one might never know what was not done or created by those who fear they would become subject to the law. This is known as the "chilling effects" doctrine.
The party is granted automatic standing by act of law. For example, under some environmental laws in the United States, a party may sue someone causing pollution to certain waterways without a federal permit, even if the party suing is not harmed by the pollution being generated. The law allows the plaintiff to receive attorney's fees if they substantially prevail in the action. In some U.S. states, a person who believes a book, film or other work of art is obscene may sue in their own name to have the work banned directly without having to ask a District Attorney to do so.In the United States, the current doctrine is that a person cannot bring a suit challenging the constitutionality of a law unless they can demonstrate that they are or will "imminently" be harmed by the law. Otherwise, the court will rule that the plaintiff "lacks standing" to bring the suit, and will dismiss the case without considering the merits of the claim of unconstitutionality.
story:
Standing, also known as locus standi, is a legal concept that determines whether a person or organization has the right to bring a lawsuit or participate in a legal case. In order to have standing, the person or organization must demonstrate a sufficient connection to the issue at hand and show that they will be harmed by it.

There are three main ways to establish standing:

1. Direct Harm: A person or organization has standing if they are directly affected by the issue and will continue to be harmed unless the court intervenes. For example, if a person is being sued for violating a law, they have standing to challenge the law because they are directly affected by it.
2. Reasonable Relation: A person or organization has standing if they can show a reasonable connection between their situation and the issue at hand, and that the issue affects others who may not be able to bring a lawsuit. For instance, if a person is not directly affected by a law but believes it violates the First Amendment, they may have standing to challenge the law because it could have a "chilling effect" on others' free speech.
3. Automatic Standing: In some cases, the law grants automatic standing to certain individuals or organizations. For example, under some environmental laws, a person may have standing to sue someone polluting waterways even if they are not directly harmed by the pollution.

In the United States, the current doctrine is that a person must demonstrate a credible threat of imminent harm in order to have standing to challenge a law's constitutionality. If a person cannot show that they are or will be harmed by the law, the court will dismiss the case without considering its merits.

In summary, standing is a legal concept that ensures that only those who have a genuine interest in a case are allowed to bring a lawsuit. It helps to prevent frivolous lawsuits and ensures that courts only hear cases that are relevant to the parties involved.

intro_text: In United States constitutional law, a state actor is a person who is acting on behalf of a governmental body, and is therefore subject to limitations imposed on government by the United States Constitution, including the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments, which prohibit the federal and state governments from violating certain rights and freedoms.
story:
Imagine you're a citizen of a small town in the United States. You have certain rights that are protected by the Constitution, such as freedom of speech, religion, and assembly. These rights are important to you because they allow you to express your opinions, practice your faith, and gather with others to advocate for changes in your community.

Now imagine that a local government official, such as the mayor or a police officer, tries to restrict your ability to exercise these rights. For example, the mayor might try to prohibit you from holding a peaceful protest in a public park, or the police officer might try to arrest you for expressing your opinion on social media.

In this situation, the government official is acting as a "state actor." This means that they are representing the government and have the power to enforce laws and regulations. However, their power is not unlimited, and they must follow the rules set forth in the Constitution.

The Constitution protects citizens from state actors who try to violate their rights. For example, the First Amendment says that the government cannot restrict your freedom of speech or religion. The Fifth Amendment says that the government cannot take your property without due process of law. The Fourteenth Amendment says that the government cannot deny you equal protection under the law.

So, if a state actor tries to restrict your rights, you can use the Constitution to defend yourself. You can argue that the government official is violating your constitutional rights and ask a court to intervene.

In summary, a state actor is a person who represents the government and has the power to enforce laws and regulations. However, their power is limited by the Constitution, which protects citizens from government overreach and ensures that they have certain fundamental rights and freedoms.

intro_text: The step transaction doctrine is a judicial doctrine in the United States that combines a series of formally separate steps, resulting in tax treatment as a single integrated event. The doctrine is often used in combination with other doctrines, such as substance over form. The doctrine is applied to prevent tax abuse, such as tax shelters or bailing assets out of a corporation. The step transaction doctrine originated from a common law principle in Gregory v. Helvering, 293 U.S. 465 (1935), which allowed the court to recharacterize a tax-motivated transaction.
story:
The step transaction doctrine is a legal principle that allows courts to treat a series of separate transactions as a single, integrated event for tax purposes. This doctrine is used to prevent tax abuse, such as tax shelters or manipulating asset values. It's like combining several separate Lego blocks into one big Lego structure, so the court can see the whole picture and not just individual pieces.

Imagine you're a smart Lego builder who wants to build a Lego castle. You start by building the base, then add some walls, a moat, and finally, a tower. But, you want to avoid paying Lego taxes on each piece, so you pretend that each piece is a separate Lego structure. The step transaction doctrine allows the Lego court to look at all the pieces together and say, "Hey, wait a minute, this is just one big Lego castle!" and tax it accordingly.

This doctrine is often used with other legal principles, like substance over form, which looks at what something is actually doing, rather than just what it's called. It's like saying, "Okay, sure, you call it a 'Lego castle,' but it's really just a pile of Lego blocks. Let's look at what it's actually doing."

The step transaction doctrine started from a court case called Gregory v. Helvering in 1935. It's like a Lego builder trying to build a castle with a secret room. The court looked at the whole structure and said, "Wait, this isn't just a room, it's a whole castle!" and taxed it accordingly.

So, the step transaction doctrine is like a Lego judge looking at a bunch of separate Lego pieces and saying, "Hey, these are all part of one big Lego structure, let's tax it that way." It helps to stop people from using fancy Lego tricks to avoid paying Lego taxes.

intro_text:
Stopping the clock is a controversial practice in American and Canadian parliamentary procedure in which a legislature literally or notionally stops the clock (or moves the hands backwards), usually for the purpose of meeting a constitutional or statutory deadline. Riddick's Rules of Procedure notes, "The official clock is stopped by agreement of the 'powers that be' without any motion or announcement one minute before the designated hour." Sometimes it is done to allow more time for lobbying or deal-making to obtain the necessary votes for one side to prevail on a measure. Some legislatures actually stop the clock, and others simply use it as a metaphor for continuing business after a time deadline has passed. Stopping the clock is also sometimes done for ceremonial purposes to ensure that both houses of a bicameral legislature adjourn simultaneously.The glossary of the Alabama State Legislature notes that the plug to the electric clock in the Senate or House chamber is sometimes pulled to allow the staff to complete the massive paper work required before sine die adjournment. 
Sometimes a legislature will even take a recess while the clock is stopped and then resume its work. The New York Legislature used to literally stop the clock at midnight on April 1 in order to pass the budget by the constitutional deadline, but eventually ended the practice and began simply disregarding the requirement. In 2004, it finally moved the deadline back to May 1.In a debate of the Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan, it was noted that stopping the clock is done by tradition and with unanimous consent, when the Opposition agrees with the Government that valuable business can be done by extending the hours. In contrast, the speaker of the Illinois Legislature unilaterally stopped the clock at midnight on the last day of its session on June 30, 1988, to allow further debate before approving money to replace Comiskey Park, a decision that ultimately passed by one vote. Had this maneuver not been done, the White Sox presumably would have moved to Florida. Stadium consultant Marc Ganis noted, "As the clock struck down in St. Petersburg, they started popping champagne corks and didn't realize that the speaker of the house can literally stop the clock in Illinois. At the stroke of midnight, we got to 60 votes."Stopping the clock is also practised in the European Union.

One potential limitation or exception is that it can only be done in cases of emergency or urgency, such as when there is a need to pass important legislation quickly in order to address a crisis or natural disaster. In such cases, stopping the clock can allow lawmakers to work together to find a solution without feeling rushed or pressured by the ticking clock. However, it is important to note that this limitation or exception should be applied judiciously and not used as a pretext for manipulating the system or circumventing established rules and procedures.

intro_text:
Subsidiarity is a principle of social organization that holds that social and political issues should be dealt with at the most immediate or local level that is consistent with their resolution. The Oxford English Dictionary defines subsidiarity as "the principle that a central authority should have a subsidiary function, performing only those tasks which cannot be performed at a more local level". The concept is applicable in the fields of government, political science, neuropsychology, cybernetics, management and in military command (mission command). The OED adds that the term "subsidiarity" in English follows the early German usage of "Subsidiaritt". More distantly, it is derived from the Latin verb subsidio (to aid or help), and the related noun subsidium (aid or assistance).
The development of the concept of subsidiarity has roots in the natural law philosophy of Thomas Aquinas and was mediated by the social scientific theories of Luigi Taparelli, SJ, in his 184043 natural law treatise on the human person in society. In that work, Taparelli established the criteria of just social order, which he referred to as "hypotactical right" and which came to be termed subsidiarity following German influences.Another origin of the concept is in the writings of Calvinist law-philosopher Johannes Althaus who used the word "subsidia" in 1603. As a principle of just social order, it became one of the pillars of modern Catholic social teaching. Subsidiarity is a general principle of European Union law. In the United States of America, Article VI, Paragraph 2 of the constitution of the United States is known as the Supremacy Clause. This establishes that the federal constitution, and federal law generally, take precedence over state laws, and even state constitutions. The principle of States' Rights is sometimes interpreted as being established by the Tenth Amendment, which says that "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people."
story:
Subsidiarity is a principle that social and political issues should be handled at the local level whenever possible. This means that instead of a central authority making decisions for everyone, decisions should be made at the most immediate level that can handle them effectively.

Imagine a group of people living in a small town. They have a problem with traffic congestion in the town square. Instead of calling the national government to come and fix the problem, the townspeople come together and decide to create a local traffic management plan. They decide to install traffic lights, create pedestrian crossings, and establish parking areas. This solution is effective because the people who live in the town know best what their community needs.

However, if the traffic problem was too big for the town to handle, they might ask the state government for help. If the state government still cannot solve the problem, then the national government might get involved. This is the essence of subsidiarity - that decisions should be made at the most local level that can handle them, and only move up to higher levels of authority when necessary.

Subsidiarity is not just applicable to government. It can also be used in other fields such as management and military command. In management, subsidiarity allows decisions to be made at the level where the most information is available, leading to more efficient decision-making. In military command, subsidiarity gives local commanders the autonomy to make decisions based on their understanding of the situation on the ground.

The concept of subsidiarity has a long history, dating back to the writings of Thomas Aquinas and Johannes Althaus. It became one of the pillars of modern Catholic social teaching and is also a principle of European Union law. In the United States, the Supremacy Clause of the Constitution establishes that federal law takes precedence over state laws, while the Tenth Amendment reserves powers not delegated to the federal government to the states or the people.

In summary, subsidiarity is a principle that social and political issues should be handled at the local level whenever possible, moving up to higher levels of authority only when necessary. It promotes efficient decision-making and allows decisions to be made by those who best understand the situation.

For example, a national government may need to intervene in a public health crisis that affects multiple states, or a global organization may need to address a global environmental issue that affects multiple countries. In such cases, subsidiarity may need to be balanced against the need for a higher level of authority to effectively address the issue.

intro_text: Substance over form is an accounting principle used "to ensure that financial statements give a complete, relevant, and accurate picture of transactions and events". If an entity practices the 'substance over form' concept, then the financial statements will convey the overall financial reality of the entity (economic substance), rather than simply reporting the legal record of transactions (form). In accounting for business transactions and other events, the measurement and reporting is for the economic impact of an event, instead of its legal form. Substance over form is critical for reliable financial reporting. It is particularly relevant in cases of revenue recognition, sale and purchase agreements, etc. The key point of the concept is that a transaction should not be recorded in such a manner as to hide the true intent of the transaction, which would mislead the readers of a company's financial statements.
story:
Imagine you are a small business owner who sells handmade artisanal candles. You have a website where customers can purchase your candles, and you also attend craft fairs to sell your products in person. One day, a large retailer approaches you and offers to buy a large quantity of candles from you. They want to pay you upfront and have you ship the candles directly to their warehouse.

Now, here's where things get a little tricky. The retailer wants to pay you in two installments: half upfront and half when the candles are delivered. However, they also want you to sign a contract that states that the ownership of the candles doesn't transfer until they have paid the second installment. This means that, technically, the candles are still yours until they have paid for them in full.

So, how would you record this transaction in your financial statements? Well, if you were to follow the principle of "substance over form," you would recognize the revenue from the sale of the candles when the retailer pays the first installment, even though technically the ownership of the candles hasn't transferred yet. This is because the economic reality of the transaction is that the retailer has paid for the candles and is now obligated to pay the remaining amount.

On the other hand, if you were to follow the legal form of the contract, you would only recognize the revenue when the second installment has been paid, and the ownership of the candles has transferred. This would give a misleading picture of your financial situation, as it would make it seem like you haven't received any revenue from the sale of the candles until the second installment has been paid.

The principle of substance over form is important because it ensures that financial statements accurately reflect the economic reality of a transaction, rather than just the legal form of the contract. In this way, it helps to prevent companies from misleading their investors and stakeholders by hiding the true intent of their transactions.

In summary, substance over form is an accounting principle that requires financial statements to reflect the economic reality of a transaction, rather than just its legal form. It's important for ensuring that financial statements are accurate and reliable, and it helps to prevent companies from misleading their investors and stakeholders.

C) Record $100,000 as revenue and $40,000 as accounts receivable.

The right answer is: C) Record $100,000 as revenue and $40,000 as accounts receivable.

In this case, the economic reality is that 'A' has sold goods worth $100,000 to 'B', even though the ownership of the goods has not yet transferred. Therefore, 'A' should record $100,000 as revenue and $40,000 as accounts receivable, as the remaining amount is still owed by 'B'.

intro_text: In law, the substantial certainty doctrine is the assumption of intent even if the actor did not intend the result, but knew with substantial certainty the effect would occur as a result of his action. The doctrine can be used by courts as a test to determine whether or not a defendant committed a tort. For example, in Garratt v. Dailey (1955), the Washington Supreme Court remanded a case back to the lower courts to determine whether or not the five year-old defendant "knew with substantial certainty that the plaintiff would attempt to sit down where the chair which he moved had been."
story: The substantial certainty doctrine is a legal principle that helps courts decide whether someone is responsible for a wrongful act, even if they didn't mean to do it. Imagine you're playing a prank on your friend by moving their chair just as they're about to sit down. If you know with a high degree of certainty that your friend will try to sit down where the chair used to be and get hurt, then you might be held responsible for their injury, even though you didn't mean to cause harm. This principle applies when someone's actions are so likely to cause harm that it's almost certain they'll happen, even if the person didn't intend them to. Courts use this doctrine to figure out if someone committed a wrongful act, like a tort, even if they claim they didn't mean to.

A) A legal principle that holds people responsible for unintended consequences of their actions only if they were very sure the harm would occur.

C) A legal principle that presumes people have the intention to cause harm if their actions are highly likely to result in harm.
D) A legal principle that allows courts to determine whether a defendant committed a tort without considering the defendant's intent.

The right answer is (A): A legal principle that holds people responsible for unintended consequences of their actions only if they were very sure the harm would occur.

In other words, even if an individual did not intend to cause harm, they may still be held liable if they had reason to believe that their actions would lead to harm. This doctrine helps courts determine whether a person has committed a tort, even if the person claims they did not intend to cause harm. Therefore, option (A) accurately describes the concept of substantial certainty doctrine.

The pedestrian suffered serious injuries and is now suing you for damages. You claim that you did not intend to hit the pedestrian and were not aware that they were crossing the street. However, witnesses testify that you were speeding at the time of the accident and that you had been warned several times before about speeding in the same area. Based on the substantial certainty doctrine, how would the court likely rule in this case?

B) The court would find you not liable for the pedestrian's injuries because you did not intend to hit them.

D) The court would find you not liable for the pedestrian's injuries because the pedestrian was partially responsible for their own injury by jaywalking.

The right answer is A) The court would find you liable for the pedestrian's injuries because you knew with substantial certainty that speeding in the area could result in an accident.

Explanation: Under the substantial certainty doctrine, if a person knows with a high degree of certainty that their actions will cause harm, they can be held liable for that harm even if they did not intend it. In this scenario, you knew or should have known that speeding in the area could result in an accident, and therefore you are liable for the pedestrian's injuries. This applies regardless of whether you intended to hit the pedestrian or not.

intro_text:
At common law, substantial performance is an alternative principle to the perfect tender rule. It allows a court to imply a term that allows a partial or substantially similar performance to stand in for the performance specified in the contract.
This principle is relevant when a contractor's performance is in some way deficient, through no willful act by the contractor, yet is so nearly equivalent that it would be unreasonable for the owner to deny the agreed upon payment. If a contractor successfully demonstrates substantial performance, the owner remains obligated to fulfill payment, less any damages suffered as a result of the deficiencies in workmanship by the contractor.
The principle is also found in the law of unilateral contracts. Unilateral contracts are contracts in which one party offers a promise in exchange for an actual performance. Traditionally, such contracts were deemed to be effective once the specified performance was tendered, and could be revoked at any time prior to completion of the performance, presenting the notorious "Cedric Brooklyn Bridge problem": in theory, A could say to B "I'll give you $100 if you walk across the Brooklyn Bridge", and then, just before B finishes crossing, pull up to him in a car and say "The deal is off," at which point no contract would be formed and A would not be liable to B for anything. This result was deemed unacceptable by many jurists and legal scholars, and applied the doctrine of substantial performance to this situation, effectively deeming someone who had begun the performance to have established an option contract to hold the unilateral contract open. This principle is enunciated in Section 237 of the Restatement (Second) of Contracts.
story:
Imagine you hired a contractor to build a house for you. The contract specifies that the house must have a certain number of bedrooms, bathrooms, and a backyard pool. However, the contractor builds the house with one less bedroom and bathroom than agreed upon, but everything else is perfect. The contractor did this unintentionally, and it would be very costly to fix the mistake. In this scenario, the principle of substantial performance would allow the court to imply a term in the contract that allows the partial performance to stand in for the agreed-upon performance. This means that the contractor would still be paid, but the owner would have the right to deduct the cost of fixing the deficiencies.

Another example is a unilateral contract, where one party promises to pay someone to do a task. For instance, someone offers $100 to anyone who can walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. Just before the person finishes crossing, the person who made the offer tries to revoke the deal. In this case, the principle of substantial performance would imply an option contract, which means that the person who started crossing the bridge has the right to hold the unilateral contract open, and the person who made the offer would have to pay them the agreed-upon amount.

In summary, substantial performance is a principle that allows a court to imply a term in a contract that allows for a partial or substantially similar performance to stand in for the agreed-upon performance. This principle is used when there is a mistake or unintentional error in the performance, and it would be unfair to deny payment. It is also applied in unilateral contracts to prevent someone from revoking the offer just before the performance is completed.

intro_text: Substantial truth is a legal doctrine affecting libel and slander laws in common law jurisdictions such as the United States or the United Kingdom.
story:
Substantial truth is a legal doctrine that helps protect people from being sued for libel or slander if the substance of what they said is true, even if some minor details are not.

Imagine a journalist writing an article about a corrupt politician. The journalist has done their research and has evidence to support their claims, but they accidentally get a few small facts wrong, such as the politician's age or the exact date they were elected. The politician sues the journalist for libel, claiming that the article damaged their reputation.

In a court of law, the judge might apply the doctrine of substantial truth to dismiss the case. This means that even though some minor details in the article were incorrect, the overall substance of the article - the fact that the politician is corrupt - is true. The judge might rule that the journalist acted responsibly and in good faith, and that the article served the public interest by exposing corruption.

The doctrine of substantial truth helps protect people who are trying to report the truth but may have made some mistakes along the way. It recognizes that it's not always possible to get every detail perfect, especially when reporting on complex issues or exposing wrongdoing. As long as the substance of what was reported is true, the court may not hold the reporter liable for minor errors.

This doctrine is important because it allows journalists, whistleblowers, and other truth-tellers to come forward without fear of being silenced by lawsuits. It helps ensure that the public has access to accurate information and that those who try to suppress the truth are held accountable.

In summary, substantial truth is a legal doctrine that protects people who report the truth, even if they get some minor details wrong. It helps ensure that the public has access to accurate information and that those who try to suppress the truth are held accountable.

intro_text: Sufficient similarity is a 20th-century para-legal concept used in the chemical industry for toxicological studies. The term was first employed in a restricted sense to assess surrogacy of chemical mixtures by the EPA, and has descended from there into the scientific argot.The concept is somewhat nebulous, and statistics are involved. A group of America researchers in 2018 posed themselves the question how similar must a product be in order to be well-represented by the tested reference sample? Because the concept was derived from the EPA, chemical similarity and biological similarity are equally important. The concept is employed "so that safety data from the tested reference can be applied to untested materials," because "when toxicity data are not available for a chemical mixture of concern, US EPA guidelines allow risk assessment to be based on data for a surrogate mixture considered sufficiently similar in terms of chemical composition and component proportions."
story:
Sufficient similarity is a concept used in the chemical industry to determine how similar a product must be to a tested reference sample in order to use the same safety data. The concept was first used by the EPA to assess the surrogacy of chemical mixtures and has since been adopted by scientists. It's important to note that both chemical and biological similarity are important when evaluating sufficient similarity.

Imagine you are a scientist working for a chemical company. Your job is to test the safety of different chemical mixtures. However, testing every single mixture would be time-consuming and expensive. That's where sufficient similarity comes in.

Let's say you have a mixture called "Mixture A" that you want to test. You also have a reference sample called "Mixture B" that has already been tested and has similar chemical and biological properties to Mixture A. If Mixture A is similar enough to Mixture B, you can use the safety data from Mixture B to assess the safety of Mixture A.

But how similar is similar enough? That's where the concept of sufficient similarity comes in. The EPA guidelines state that a surrogate mixture can be used for risk assessment if it is "sufficiently similar" in terms of chemical composition and component proportions.

To determine sufficient similarity, you would compare the chemical composition and component proportions of Mixture A and Mixture B. You would use statistical methods to evaluate the similarity between the two mixtures. If the similarity is high enough, you can use the safety data from Mixture B to assess the safety of Mixture A.

In summary, sufficient similarity is a way to determine how similar a product must be to a tested reference sample in order to use the same safety data. intro_text: In United States constitutional law, a suspect classification is a class or group of persons meeting a series of criteria suggesting they are likely the subject of discrimination. These classes receive closer scrutiny by courts when an Equal Protection claim alleging unconstitutional discrimination is asserted against a law, regulation, or other government action, or sometimes private action. When a law or government action affects a group that falls under a "suspect classification," courts apply the strict scrutiny standard in reviewing the constitutional validity of a law or action.
story:
Imagine you are a member of a club that is known for being exclusive and discriminatory. The club has a history of denying membership to people of certain races, religions, or genders. One day, the club passes a rule that only allows members who are over 6 feet tall. While the rule may seem neutral at first glance, it disproportionately affects people of certain races or ethnicities who are less likely to be over 6 feet tall.

If someone from one of these groups challenges the rule, claiming it is discriminatory, the court will look closely at the rule and consider whether it unfairly targets certain groups. This is known as a "suspect classification." The court will apply a higher standard of review, known as "strict scrutiny," to determine whether the rule is constitutional.

In this case, the club's rule is a suspect classification because it disproportionately affects certain groups that have historically been subject to discrimination. The court will closely examine the rule to ensure that it is not discriminatory and that it serves a compelling government interest.

In summary, a suspect classification is a group of people who have historically been subject to discrimination and who may be unfairly targeted by a law or rule. Courts apply a higher standard of review to ensure that these groups are not being discriminated against unfairly.

intro_text:
Taint is a term used in the legal field with reference to evidence that has been "tainted" or ruined in some manner. The most common of such usage is with reference to evidence, testimony, identification by witnesses, or confessions that have been obtained by law enforcement illegally. The illegality usually results from a violation of one's constitutional rights, such as a violation of the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution protecting against unreasonable search and seizure. For example, the dissent in the Supreme Court decision of Missouri v. Seibert stated that "the court must examine whether the taint dissipated through the passing of time ... ." Missouri v. Seibert, 542 U.S. 600, 628 (U.S. 2004) (Justice O'Connor Dissent, emphasis added). The court in Wong Sun v. U.S., discussed "purg[ing] of the primary taint" with reference to allowing evidence because the defendant's statements were voluntary and a lengthy period of time had passed as an intervening act. Wong Sun v. U.S., 371 U.S. 471, (1963) (quoting J. Maguire, Evidence of Guilt 221 (1959) (emphasis added) (stating: "... by means sufficiently distinguishable to be purged of the primary taint.")).
Investigators sometimes employ a "filter team," or "taint team," composed of individuals not involved in an investigation, to prevent investigators from seeing information that could taint evidence, such as information protected by attorney-client privilege.
story:
Imagine you're a detective trying to solve a mystery. You find a clue that could help you catch the culprit, but you're not sure if you can use it. That's because the clue was obtained illegally - maybe you searched someone's house without a warrant, or you forced someone to tell you what they know.

In legal terms, the clue is said to be "tainted". This means it's not reliable, and it could get in the way of a fair trial. The law wants to make sure that only reliable evidence is used in court, so it has rules to prevent tainted evidence from being introduced.

But what if the clue is really important? Is it always impossible to use? Not necessarily. The law recognizes that sometimes, time can heal all wounds. If enough time passes between when the evidence was obtained illegally and when it's presented in court, the taint might "dissipate". This means that the evidence might become reliable again.

Imagine you're a detective again. You find a suspect's confession that was obtained illegally. But you also have other evidence that proves the suspect's guilt, and you want to use the confession to strengthen your case. The court might allow you to use the confession if it's been a long time since it was obtained, and there's no other way to get the same information.

There's another way to prevent evidence from being tainted: using a "filter team" or "taint team". This is a group of people who are not involved in the investigation, and their job is to make sure that the investigators don't see any information that could taint the evidence. It's like having a separate team of detectives who only look at the reliable clues, so they can't accidentally ruin the case by seeing something they shouldn't.

In summary, tainted evidence is evidence that's not reliable because it was obtained illegally. The law tries to prevent tainted evidence from being used in court, but there are exceptions. If enough time passes, the taint might dissipate, and the evidence might become reliable again. Filter teams can also help to prevent evidence from being tainted in the first place.

intro_text: The Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine or remote, good-faith user doctrine is a common law rule of United States trademark law that determines the geographic scope of rights.  The doctrine allows a junior user of a mark that is geographically remote from the senior user of the mark to establish priority over a senior user's claim to the mark in the junior user's area.  The constructive use and notice sections of the Lanham Act limited the applicability of this doctrine.
story:
The Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine is a legal principle in US trademark law that helps determine the geographic scope of trademark rights. It allows a business that uses a trademark in a different geographic area than an existing business with the same trademark to have priority over the existing business's claim to the trademark in the new area, as long as the new business is not trying to expand into the existing business's area and is not known to the existing business.

But, Rectanus also knew that it had been using the trademark in good faith in Los Angeles for many years, and it didn't want to give up its rights to the mark. That's when it learned about the Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine.

The doctrine allowed Rectanus to continue using the trademark in Los Angeles, even though Tea Rose had priority in New York City. This was because Rectanus was a "junior user" of the mark, meaning it started using the mark after Tea Rose, and it was geographically remote from Tea Rose's area of use.

This allowed Rectanus to protect its investment in the trademark and continue to grow its business in Los Angeles.

In summary, the Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine helps businesses like Rectanus protect their trademark rights in different geographic areas, as long as they are not trying to interfere with existing businesses with the same trademark. intro_text: The tender years doctrine is a legal principle in family law since the late 19th century. In common law, it presumes that during a child's "tender" years (generally regarded as the age of four and under), the mother should have custody of the child. The doctrine often arises in divorce proceedings.
story:
The tender years doctrine is a legal principle that favors granting child custody to the mother during a child's early years, typically up to the age of four, in divorce proceedings.

Story:

Meet Sarah and John, a couple who have been married for over a decade and have two young children, Emily (4) and Max (2). Unfortunately, their marriage has been on shaky ground lately, and they have decided to go their separate ways. As they begin the process of divorce, they must now face the difficult decision of determining who will have custody of their children.

Sarah, being the primary caregiver and nurturer of their children, believes that she should have full custody of Emily and Max. She has been the one to take them to school, cook their meals, and put them to bed every night. John, on the other hand, argues that he has also been an active parent and should have joint custody.

Their divorce lawyer explains the tender years doctrine to them, stating that in cases like theirs, the court tends to favor the mother during the children's tender years, which are generally considered to be up to the age of four. This is because young children require a lot of care and attention, and the mother has typically been the primary caregiver.

Sarah feels a sense of relief knowing that the law may be on her side. She has always put her children's needs first and cannot imagine not being able to be there for them during these critical early years. John, however, is disappointed. He feels that he has been a good father and should have an equal say in their children's upbringing.

Their lawyer encourages them to work together to find a custody arrangement that works for everyone. Sarah and John agree to share joint custody, with Sarah having primary physical custody during the week and John having visitation rights every weekend. They also agree to review and adjust the arrangement as their children grow older and their needs change.

In the end, Sarah and John put their children's needs first and work together to ensure a smooth transition for their family. The tender years doctrine provides a helpful guidance for them to make decisions that are in the best interests of their children.

intro_text: Terra nullius (, plural terrae nullius) is a Latin expression meaning "nobody's land". It was a principle sometimes used in international law to justify claims that territory may be acquired by a state's occupation of it. There are currently three territories sometimes claimed to be terra nullius: Bir Tawil (a strip of land between Egypt and Sudan), 4 pockets of land near the Danube due to the CroatiaSerbia border dispute, and parts of Antarctica, principally Marie Byrd Land.
story:
Terra nullius is a Latin expression that means "nobody's land." It's like a rule in a game where if a piece of land doesn't belong to anyone, anyone can take it. This idea was used in the past to justify taking over land that didn't belong to any country. There are a few places in the world that are considered "nobody's land" right now, like a strip of land between Egypt and Sudan, some land near the Danube river that Croatia and Serbia are fighting over, and some parts of Antarctica.

Well, that's where the concept of terra nullius comes in. Terra nullius is like a rule that says if a piece of land doesn't belong to anyone, it's up for grabs. It's like finding a lost treasure chest - if no one else has claimed it, you get to keep it!

This limitation is important because it helps to prevent conflicts over land ownership and ensures that countries respect each other's territorial claims.

intro_text: The territorial principle (also territoriality principle) is a principle of public international law which enables a sovereign state to exercise exclusive jurisdiction over individuals and other legal persons within its territory. It includes both the right to prosecute individuals for criminal offences committed within its borders, as well as the right to arrest and apprehend individuals within its territory. Its corollary bars states from exercising jurisdiction within the territory of other states without their express consent, unless such an exercise can be based on other principles of jurisdiction, such as the principle of nationality, the passive personality principle, the protective principle, and possibly, the principle of universal jurisdiction.The Lotus case was a key court ruling on the territoriality principle. In 1926, a French vessel collided with a Turkish vessel, causing the death of several Turkish nationals. The Permanent Court of International Justice ruled, by a bare majority, that Turkey had jurisdiction to try the French naval lieutenant for criminal negligence, even though the incident happened beyond Turkey's boundaries. This case extended the territoriality principle to cover cases that happen outside a state's boundaries, but have a substantial effect on the state's interests or involve its citizens.Questions have surfaced regarding how the territoriality principle applies with the rise of globalization and the Internet. The applicability of this principle was in question with the case against Augusto Pinochet and other cases of transnational justice.
story:
The territorial principle is a rule in international law that gives a country the power to control what happens within its own borders. This means that a country can arrest and prosecute people who commit crimes within its territory, and no other country can interfere with that power without permission.

Imagine your country is like a big house, and you're the homeowner. You get to decide who comes in and out, and you make the rules for what happens inside your house. If someone breaks the rules, you can punish them. That's kind of like what the territorial principle does for countries.

Now, imagine that your neighbor's house is right next door to yours. If someone breaks the rules in your neighbor's house, you can't just go in and arrest them without your neighbor's permission. That would be like violating their privacy and space. The same thing goes for countries. If a crime happens in another country, that country gets to decide who to punish and how, unless they ask for help from another country.

There have been some questions about how this principle works in today's world, especially with the internet and globalization. It's like wondering if someone can commit a crime in your house while they're standing in their own house next door. It can get a bit confusing! But basically, the territorial principle is all about respecting each country's power to control what happens within its own borders.

intro_text:
The Tipsy Coachman doctrine is a rule of law that upholds in a higher court a correct conclusion, despite flawed reasoning by the judge in a lower court. In other words, the lower judgment was right but for the wrong reason.
The colorful "tipsy coachman" label comes from a 19th-century Georgia case, Lee v. Porter, 63 Ga 345, 346 (1879), in which the Georgia Supreme Court, noting that the "human mind is so constituted that in many instances it finds the truth when wholly unable to find the way that leads to it," quoted from Oliver Goldsmith's Retaliation: A Poem written in 1774:

Here, waiter, more wine, let me sit while I'm able,
'Till all my companions sink under the table;
Then, with chaos and blunders encircling my head,
Let me ponder, and tell what I think of the dead.
...Here lies honest William, whose heart was a mint,
While the owner ne'er knew half the good that was in't;
The pupil of impulse, it forced him along,
His conduct still right, with his argument wrong;
Still aiming at honour, yet fearing to roam,
The coachman was tipsy, the chariot drove home;
Would you ask for his merits, alas! he had none,
What was good was spontaneous, his faults were his own.The Florida Supreme Court explained the doctrine in a 2002 appeal from a second-degree murder conviction:
We start with the proposition that generally, if a claim is not raised in the [trial] court, it will not be considered on appeal. However, notwithstanding this principle, in some circumstances, even though a trial court's ruling is based on improper reasoning, the ruling will be upheld if there is any theory or principle of law in the record which would support the ruling. [] This longstanding principle of appellate law, sometimes referred to as the tipsy coachman doctrine, allows an appellate court to affirm a trial court that reaches the right result but for the wrong reasons so long as there is any basis which would support the judgment in the record." Robertson v. State, 829 So. 2d 901, 906 (Fla. 2002) (internal citations and punctuation omitted).
story:
The Tipsy Coachman doctrine is a legal principle that allows a higher court to uphold a lower court's decision, even if the lower court's reasoning was flawed, as long as there is a valid legal basis for the decision in the record.

This doctrine allows the higher court to look beyond the lower court's faulty reasoning and focus on whether there is any valid legal basis for the decision in the record.

In other words, just as the tipsy coachman still managed to drive the carriage to the correct destination, a lower court's decision may still be upheld even if the reasoning was incorrect, as long as there is a legal basis for the decision in the record. This doctrine helps ensure that justice is served, even when the lower court's reasoning was not perfect.

intro_text:
Tolling is a legal doctrine that allows for the pausing or delaying of the running of the period of time set forth by a statute of limitations, such that a lawsuit may potentially be filed even after the statute of limitations has run. Although grounds for tolling the statute of limitations vary by jurisdiction, common grounds include:
The plaintiff was a minor at the time a cause of action accrued.
The plaintiff has been deemed mentally incompetent.
The plaintiff has been convicted of a felony and is imprisoned.
The defendant has filed a bankruptcy case triggering a stay of other lawsuits.
The defendant is not physically within a certain jurisdiction (state or country).
The parties were engaged in good-faith negotiations to resolve a dispute without litigation when the statute of limitations expired.Tolling may occur under a statute that specifically provides for the tolling of the statute of limitations during specified circumstances. It may also take the form of equitable tolling, where the court applies common law principles of equity to extend the time for the filing of a document.
story:
Tolling is a legal doctrine that allows the clock to stop ticking on a statute of limitations, giving someone extra time to file a lawsuit even after the deadline has passed. This can happen for several reasons, such as if the person filing the lawsuit was a minor, mentally incompetent, in prison, or out of the country when the deadline passed. It can also happen if the other party filed for bankruptcy, or if the two sides were in the process of negotiating a settlement when the deadline expired. In some cases, tolling can be automatic under a specific statute, while in other cases, it may be granted by a court using equitable principles.

Story:

As the statute of limitations approached, Jane's parents finally found a lawyer who was willing to take her case. However, the lawyer realized that Jane was still a minor and that the statute of limitations had already run out. Feeling hopeless, Jane's parents were about to give up when the lawyer explained the concept of tolling to them.

The lawyer told them that because Jane was a minor when the accident happened, the statute of limitations was tolled, or paused, until she turned 18. This meant that she had until her 18th birthday to file a lawsuit against the driver who hit her.

Jane's parents were thrilled to hear this and immediately filed the lawsuit on her behalf. The case went to court, and Jane was able to recover damages for her injuries. If it weren't for tolling, Jane would have been out of luck and would have never been able to pursue her claim.

In this example, tolling allowed Jane to file her lawsuit even though the statute of limitations had already passed. It gave her extra time to prepare her case and seek justice for her injuries.

intro_text:
The totality principle is a common law principle which applies when a court imposes multiple sentences of imprisonment. The principle was first formulated by David Thomas in his 1970 study of the sentencing decisions of the Court of Appeal of England and Wales:
The effect of the totality principle is to require a sentencer who has passed a series of sentences, each properly calculated in relation to the offence for which it is imposed and each properly made consecutive in accordance with the principles governing consecutive sentences, to review the aggregate sentence and consider whether the aggregate is 'just and appropriate'. The principle has been stated many times in various forms: 'when a number of offences are being dealt with and specific punishments in respect of them are being totted up to make a total, it is always necessary for the court to take a last look at the total just to see whether it looks wrong'; 'when ... cases of multiplicity of offences come before the court, the court must not content itself by doing the arithmetic and passing the sentence which the arithmetic produces. It must look at the totality of the criminal behaviour and ask itself what is the appropriate sentence for all the offences.'
story:
The totality principle is a legal principle that helps judges decide the appropriate total sentence when someone has been found guilty of multiple crimes. It ensures that the total sentence is fair and suitable for all the offenses committed.

Imagine a person, John, who has been found guilty of three crimes: theft, vandalism, and assault. The judge has to decide the sentence for each crime and then decide how the sentences will run together. The totality principle comes into play when the judge is deciding the total sentence.

The judge starts by sentencing John for theft. They give him a sentence of six months in prison. Then, they move on to the vandalism charge and give him another six months in prison, to run consecutively with the first sentence. Finally, they sentence him to 12 months in prison for the assault charge, also to run consecutively.

In total, John would serve 24 months in prison. But, the judge has to apply the totality principle. They review the total sentence and think, "Is 24 months in prison really appropriate for all three crimes?" They might decide that 24 months is too harsh, considering John's criminal history and other factors.

So, the judge decides to reduce the sentence for one of the crimes, let's say the vandalism charge, to three months in prison. Now, John's total sentence would be 18 months in prison. The judge believes this is a more appropriate sentence, considering the totality of John's criminal behavior.

In summary, the totality principle helps judges ensure that the total sentence is fair and suitable for all the crimes committed. It allows them to take a step back, review the total sentence, and make adjustments if necessary.

intro_text:
Transnational child protection refers to the protection of children from violence, exploitation, abuse and neglect in an international setting. When a non-national child comes into contact with public authorities and service providers, a series of checks, assessments and immediate measures sets in to identify the child and to assess her or his situation. Article 19 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child provides for the protection of children in and out of the home, including in their country of origin, residence or a third country. Article 2 of the Convention provides for the right to non-discrimination, meaning children have the right to protection regardless of the national origin or status of the child or his or her parents or legal guardians.
A child may become party to a transnational child protection case because of a need for protection, including: due to international adoption, being born to parents with different or multiple nationalities, being born in a different country than either parent's nationality, and migrating or being trafficked. Being an unaccompanied or separated minor comes with particular challenges.
story:

Imagine a young girl named Leila. She was born in a small village in Africa, but her parents were from different countries. When Leila was just a baby, her family moved to Europe, where they sought asylum. She was placed in foster care, but the social workers realized that Leila was not safe in her new home. They suspected that she was being abused and decided to investigate.

After conducting a series of assessments and checks, the social workers discovered that Leila was indeed being harmed. They immediately took action to protect her and placed her in a safe home. They also worked with authorities in Leila's country of origin to ensure that she would not be sent back to a dangerous situation.

This is just one example of how transnational child protection works. In this case, Leila's situation was complicated by her nationality and immigration status. However, the social workers and authorities worked together to ensure that she was protected and safe, regardless of her background.
